FEE RESOLUTION
A Resolution establishing fees for the filing of applications, permits and
licenses for the Township of Hanover, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania.
WHEREAS, the Township Council of the Township of Hanover has adopted a
codification, consolidation and revision of the ordinances of the Township of
Hanover, and;
WHEREAS, it is the desire of the Township Council of the Township of Hanover to
eliminate all filing fees, permit fees, and license fees from the Code of
Ordinances and enact them instead by Resolution;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED and it is hereby resolved by the Township
Council of the Township of Hanover that all fees are hereby fixed as follows:
                                                                                      UNIT FEE

SEWERS
   Connection Fee (18, §
18-302)   The sewer connection fee shall be $1,000 for each dwelling unit or, if
not a residential use, $1,000 for each equivalent dwelling unit ("EDU"), or part
thereof, of sewage discharge. An EDU is 262.5 gallons per day of sewage
effluent.
(Res. 1996-48)

BUILDING PERMIT FEES
1.   Permit issuance fee as follows:
                                                                   $2/$1,000 or
   A.   Uniform fee for alterations, new construction or     fraction
demolition                                                         thereof -
                                                                   minimum of $20
2.   Any person who commences any work requiring the issuance of a permit pursuant
to the uniform Construction Code, Zoning Ordinance, the Building, Plumbing,
Mechanical, Electrical and Fire Prevention Codes, before obtaining the necessary
permits, shall be subject to 100% of the usual permit fee for such work in
addition to the required permit fee.
(Res. 2020-32)
3.   Consultant/contracted service fees, Uniform Construction Code. Where the
Township contracts with any third-party agency for the review of plans of
enforcement of codes as is required under the Pennsylvania Uniform Construction
Code (PA Act 45), the permit applicant shall be responsible for the payment of all
fees associated with the enforcement of the codes including, but not limited to,
plan review, inspection, permit and hourly consultation fees. Said fees shall be
as established from time to time by the Council as submitted by the contracting
agency for performing such services. All such fees shall include a municipal
administrative fee and PA Act 13 surcharge.
(Res. 2021-27)
                                                                   
PLUMBING AND ELECTRICAL PERMIT FEES                                 
1.   Residential - new construction and alterations
   A.   Plumbing                                             $50
   B.   Electrical                                           $50
2.   Miscellaneous new construction and alterations              
   A.   Storage tanks exceeding 100 gallons                  $25

alterations
                                                                   $100 + $4/
   A.   Plumbing - first three fixtures                      additional
                                                                   fixtures
   B.   Electrical - first three fixtures                    $100
4.   Appeals to the Building Board of Approval                  $1,000
NOTE 1   All plumbing permits must be picked up by persons holding a Masters
Plumber's License obtained by written examination.
      Exemption: Homeowner occupied one and two-family dwellings - homeowner may
pick up permit and will be subject to all inspections.
NOTE 2   All electrical permits must be picked up by persons holding a Masters
Electrician's License obtained by written examination.
      Exemption: Homeowner occupied one and two-family dwellings - homeowner may
pick up permit and will be subject to all inspections.
 
 
REINSPECTION OF EXISTING PROPERTIES
   Reinspection of existing properties shall be based upon the square feet of
all floors including the basement $150 for the first 1,000 square feet plus $5
for each additional five hundred square feet thereafter or fraction thereof
provided there shall be a minimum charge of at least $175 if no violations are
found, and at least $275 (including two inspections) if violations are present.
The maximum initial fee shall be $1,000, except in no case shall the fee be less
than $175 or $275 per tenant. Any time that is spent on inspections made over
and above time and inspections included in the initial fee shall be invoiced at
a rate or $65 per hour.

HOME RULE CHARTER  *
 
Notes
     Unless otherwise indicated, all provisions of the Home Rule Charter are as
  contained in the August 1, 1976, Government Study Commission Report, approved by
  the electorate by referendum in the November 2, 1976, general election.
*  
     By Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election all nouns, pronouns and adjectives were
  changed throughout the Charter to gender neutral forms.
PREAMBLE
   We, the People of Hanover Township, in order to promote economy, efficiency,
and effectiveness in Township government and in order to assure each citizen
the right to participate in Township government hereby adopt this Home Rule
Charter under the Constitution and laws of Pennsylvania. No provision of this
charter, and no action by any officer or employee of the Township acting under
its authority, shall infringe upon rights, privileges and powers reserved or
guaranteed to individual persons or to the people by the Constitution of the
United States of America or the Constitution of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania.
Article I
General Provisions
Section 1.01 Title.
This charter shall be known as the “Home Rule Charter of Hanover Township,
Lehigh County, Pennsylvania.”
Section 1.02 Name.
Hanover Township shall continue to be a municipal corporation under its present
name, “Hanover Township.”
Section 1.03 Boundaries.
The boundaries of the Township shall be the actual boundaries of the Township
at the time this charter takes effect and as they may be lawfully changed
thereafter.
Section 1.04 Definitions.
The following words, when used in this charter, shall unless the context
clearly indicates otherwise, mean or include as follows:
   appropriate:   Township funds set apart for or assigned to a particular
purpose or use in the annual budget.
   appropriation:   Township funds that have been appropriated after which such
money is set aside by formal action for a specific use.
   charter:   The Home Rule Charter of Hanover Township, Lehigh County,
Pennsylvania.
   clerk:   Clerk of the Township; Township clerk; Clerk of Council.
   council:   The governing body of the Township as defined in Article III.
   councilperson:   An elected or appointed member of the Township Council.
   Court of Common Pleas:   The Court of Common Pleas of Lehigh County,
Pennsylvania.
   defalcation 1 :   Embezzlement or misappropriation of Township funds for
personal or other non-Township purposes.
   employee:   A Township employee is one employed by the Township for wages or
salary and in a position below the level of a legislative, executive or
professional person.
   encumbered:   Funds by an appropriation which have been legally obligated by
means of contracts, payments due or upcoming or debt service.
   motion:   A proposal and formal action by council on matters before council.
   officer:   A representative of the Township who has been appointed to an
office as provided by the provisions of the charter.
   official:   An elected representative of the Township which is enumer ated
in this charter.
   ordinance:   A law set forth by the authority granted the Township which
applies to an order governing some detail of procedure or conduct enforced by
the authority of the municipality.
   person:   An individual, partnership, association, corporation or other
entity unless such a construction would be unreason able.
   quorum:   Three (3) of the five (5) council members.
   resolution:   Is a formal expression of an opinion, will, or intent of such
importance or length as to be in writing and for the purpose of this charter
shall include a preamble setting forth the reasons for the opinion, will or
intent.
   state:   The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
   Statutory Code:   A volume containing ordinances, resolutions and charter
amendments of Hanover Township which ordinances, resolutions and charter
amendments have the force and effect of law.
   supervisor:   An elected Township official as defined in the Code of
Township of the Second Class, Act 567 of July 10, 1947, P.L. 1481 as amended.
   Township:   “Township” shall mean the Township of Hanover, Lehigh County,
Pennsylvania.
   work program:   A detailed written plan setting forth the objectives and
financial plan of each department, office or agency.
 
Notes
1    Amended by Section 3 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 1.05 Gender.
Words used in the masculine gender shall include the feminine.
Section 1.06 Township Seal.
The council shall have the power to adopt the official seal for the Township.
Section 1.07 Planning.
The Township shall be subject to the provisions of the Pennsylvania
Municipalities Planning Code, Act of July 31, 1968, P.L. 805 as amended.
Section 1.08 Township Elections.
The provisions of the general election laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
shall apply to elections held under this charter. All elections provided for by
the charter shall be conducted by the election authorities established by law.
Section 1.09 Eminent Domain.
The Township shall be subject to the provisions of the Pennsylvania Eminent
Domain Code, as amended. 2
 
Notes
2    Amended by Section 4 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 1.10 Separability.
If any provision of this charter is held invalid, the other provisions of the
charter shall not be affected thereby. If the application of the charter or any
of its provisions to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the
application of the charter and its provisions to other persons or circumstances
shall not be affected thereby.
Section 1.11 Amendments.
This charter shall be amended in accordance with the law of Pennsylvania.
Article II
Powers Of The Township
Section 2.01 Powers of the Township.
The Township shall have all powers possible for a Township to have under the
Constitution and laws of this state as fully and completely as though they were
specifically enumerated in this charter.
Section 2.01 Construction.
The powers of the Township under this charter shall be construed liberally in
favor of the Township, and the specific mention of particular powers in this
charter shall not be construed as limiting in any way the general power stated
in this article.
Section 2.03 Intergovernmental Relations.
The Township may exercise any of its powers or perform any of its functions and
may participate in the financing thereof, jointly or in cooperation, by
contract or otherwise, with any one or more states or civil divisions or
agencies thereof, or the United States or any agency thereof.
Article III
Township Council
Status and Title. The legislative branch of the government of Hanover Township
shall consist of an elective governing body which shall be known as the
Township Council. The Council, when lawfully convened shall constitute the
legislative, appropriating, policy-determining and governing body of the
municipality.
Section 3.01 Composition; Eligibility; Terms and Election
   (a)   Composition. There shall be a council of five members elected at large
by the qualified voters of the Township.
   (b)   Eligibility. Only qualified electors of the Township shall be eligible
to be members of the council, and such qualifications shall include residency
within the Township during any term in office. 1
   (c)   Terms and Election. The terms of office of all councilmen shall be
four (4) years, commencing on the first Monday of January, next following the
year in which they are elected and ending at the commencement of the terms for
which their successors are elected; except that a councilperson elected to fill
a vacancy shall serve only two (2) years. The regular election of councilmen
shall be held in each odd numbered year pursuant to the Pennsylvania Election
Code. At the first election under this charter, three councilmen shall be
elected; the two candidates receiving the greatest number of votes shall serve
terms of four (4) years, and the one candidate receiving the next greatest
number of votes shall serve a term of two (2) years. Thereafter, and at all
subsequent municipal elections, a number of councilmen shall be elected as
required to make up a Township council of five (5) members. Supervisors in
office at the time of adoption of this charter shall continue in office until
their terms expire.
 
Notes
1    Amended by Section 5 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 3.02 Compensation; Expenses. 2   
The initial salary of each councilperson shall be $20.00 for each official
meeting attended. However, no councilperson shall receive an aggregate salary
exceeding $2,500.00 per annum. This provision shall not be construed as a
limitation upon the number of meetings held in any given fiscal year. The
council shall make any adjustments in this salary solely by ordinance, but no
ordinance adjusting such salary shall become effective until the date of
commencement of the terms of councilmen elected at the next regular municipal
election, provided that such election follows the adoption of such ordinance by
at least ten (10) months. Councilmen shall be entitled to receive their actual
and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties of office.
However, they shall receive no life insurance, pensions, or other form of
fringe benefits.
 
Notes
     Editor’s Note: Section 3.02 amended to limit the maximum aggregate salary for
2 a member of council to $2,500.00 per year as proposed by Ord. 416, 2/6/2002, and
  approval of the referendum question by the electorate in the May, 2002, Primary
  Election.
Section 3.03 Chairperson.
The council shall elect from among its members officers of the Township who
shall have the titles of chairperson and vice- chairperson, each of whom shall
serve at the pleasure of the council. The chairperson shall preside at meetings
of the council, shall be recognized as head of the Township government for all
ceremonial purposes and by the governor for purposes of military law but shall
have no administrative duties. The vice- chairperson shall act as chairperson
during the absence or disability of the chairperson.
Section 3.04 General Powers and Duties.
All powers of the Township shall be vested in the council, except as otherwise
provided by law or this charter, and the council shall provide for the exercise
thereof and for the performance of all duties and obligations imposed on the
Township by law or this charter.
Section 3.05 Prohibitions.
   (a)   Holding Other Office. No councilperson shall hold any other Township
office or Township employment during the terms for which he/she was elected or
appointed to the council, and no former councilperson shall hold any
compensated appointive Township office or Township employment until one year
after the expiration of the term for which he/she was elected or appointed to
the council.
   (b)   Appointments and Removals. Neither the council nor any of its members
shall in any manner dictate the appointment or removal of any Township
administrative officers or employees whom the manager or any of his/her
subordinates are empowered to appoint.
   (c)   Interference with Administration. Except for the purpose of inquiries
and investigations under Section 3.08, the council or its members shall deal
with Township officers and employees who are subject to the direction and
supervision of the manager solely through the manager, and neither the council
nor its members shall give orders to any such officer or employee, either
publicly or privately.
Section 3.06 Vacancies; Filling of Vacancies. 3
   (a)   Vacancies. The office of a councilperson shall become vacant upon his/
her death, resignation, failure to assume such office after election or
appointment thereto within forty-five (45) days after commencement of the term
thereof, or removal from office in any manner authorized by law.
   (b)   Filling of Vacancies. If a vacancy shall occur in the office of a
member of the council for any reason set forth in this charter, the remaining
members of the council shall fill such vacancy by appointing a person qualified
under this charter to hold such office until the end of the term or until the
first Monday of January following the next regular municipal election at which
a person is elected to serve the remainder of the term, whichever is sooner. If
the members of the council shall refuse, fail or neglect, or be unable for any
reason whatsoever, to fill such vacancy within forty-five (45) days after the
vacancy occurs, then the Court of Common Pleas shall, upon petition of any
member of the council or of any five citizens of the Township, fill the vacancy
in such office by the appointment of a qualified resident of the Township
within 30 days after the filing of such petition. Notwithstanding the
requirement in Section 3.10 that a quorum of the council consists of three
members, if at any time the membership of the council is reduced to less than
three, the remaining members may by majority action appoint additional members
to raise the membership to three. 4
