Section 3.08 Investigations.
The council may make investigations into the affairs of the Township and the
conduct of any Township department, office or agency and for this purpose may
subpoena witnesses, administer oaths, take testimony and require the production
of evidence. Any person residing outside the Township and subpoenaed as
aforesaid, shall not be required to respond to the same until mileage and
witness fees, equal to those then established for witnesses whose attendance
has been required by the Court of Common Pleas of Lehigh County, shall have
been first furnished to the witness. All witnesses required to provide
information shall be accorded the same privileges and immunities as witnesses
whose attendance has been required by the Court of Common Pleas of Lehigh
County. Any person who fails or refuses to obey a lawful order issued in the
exercise of these powers by the council shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
punishable under the provisions of the Crimes Code of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania or succeeding Pennsylvania criminal laws. 6
 
Notes
6    Last sentence amended by Section 1 or Ord. 550, 12/8/2013, approved by
  Referendum at the November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 3.09 Independent Audit.
The council shall provide for an independent annual audit of all Township
accounts and may provide for more frequent audits as it deems necessary. Such
audits shall be made by a certified public accountant registered in
Pennsylvania, a firm of certified public accountants so registered or a
competent public accountant or a competent firm of public accountants who have
no personal interest, direct or indirect, in the fiscal affairs of the Township
government of any of its officers. The council shall contract with such
accountant or firm annually or for a period not exceeding three years, provided
that the contract for any particular fiscal year shall be made no later than 30
days after the beginning of such fiscal year.
Section 3.10 Procedure.
   (a)   Meetings. The council shall meet the second Monday in January of each
year for the purpose of organization. At this meeting, the council shall elect
officers as prescribed in Section 3.03. This organizational meeting may be
considered as a regular monthly meeting for the transaction of such business as
may be presented. Thereafter, the council shall meet regularly at least once
every month at such times and places as the council may prescribe by
resolutions. Special meetings may be held on the call of the chairperson or of
three (3) or more members. Three (3) days notice shall be given to each council
member personally. Emergency meetings, for matters imminently affecting life,
health, property or the public peace, may be called whenever necessary by the
Township manager pursuant to Section 4.06, upon no less than twelve (12) hours
notice to three (3) or more council members. However, if council members deem
it necessary, an emergency meeting may be held upon less than twelve (12) hours
notice. All meetings shall be public. However, the council may recess for the
purpose of discussing in a closed or executive session limited to its own
membership any matter which would tend to defame or prejudice the character or
reputation of any person, provided that the general subject matter for
consideration is expressed in the motion calling for such session and that
final action thereon shall not be taken by the council until the matter is
placed on the agenda. Public notice for meetings of council shall be as
prescribed by the Pennsylvania Sunshine Act as it may be amended. 7
   (b)   Rules and Journal. The council shall by ordinance determine its rules
and order of business and shall provide for keeping a journal of its
proceedings. The format of this journal shall be retained each year thereafter.
This journal shall be a public record.
   (c)   Voting. Voting, except on procedural motions, shall be by roll call
and the ayes and nays shall be recorded in the journal. Three (3) members of
the council shall constitute a quorum, but a smaller number may adjourn from
time to time, and may compel the attendance of absent members in the manner and
subject to the penalties prescribed by the resolutions of the council. No
action of the council, except as otherwise provided in the preceding sentence
and in Section 3.06, shall be valid and binding unless adopted by the
affirmative vote of the members of the council. The vote of a majority of the
members of the council shall be required for the adoption of an ordinance,
resolution, or budget, unless otherwise provided by this charter. The vote of a
majority of the members of the council present shall be required for the
adoption of a motion.
 
Notes
7    Notice provisions amended by Section 7 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by
  Referendum at the November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 3.11 Citizen’s Right to Be Heard.
The council shall provide reasonable opportunity for persons to address the
council during its meetings. No ordinance, ordinance amendment, resolution, or
motion may be adopted without the council having provided reasonable
opportunity for the citizens and taxpayers of the Township to address the
council before a vote is taken. The council shall, by ordinance, adopt
procedures for citizens participation.
Section 3.12 Actions Requiring an Ordinance.
   In addition to other acts required by state or federal laws or by specific
provisions of this charter to be done by ordinance, those acts of the Township
council shall be by ordinance which:
      1.   Adopt or amend an administrative code or establish, alter or abolish
any Township department, office or agency which the council has established.
      2.   Provide for a fine or other penalty or establish a rule or
regulation for violation of which a fine or other penalty is imposed.
      3.   Levy taxes.
      4.   Grant, renew or extend a franchise.
      5.   Establish and regulate the rate charged for its services by public
utility provided by the Township.
      6.   Authorize the borrowing of money.
      7.   Convey or lease or authorize the conveyance or lease of any lands of
the Township.
      8.   Adopt with or without amendment ordinance proposed under the
initiative power.
      9.   Amend or repeal any ordinance previously adopted, except as
otherwise provided in Article IX with respect to repeal of ordinances
reconsidered under the referendum power.
      10.   Exercise eminent domain.
      11.   Adopt a budget.
   Acts other than those referred to in this section may be done by ordinance,
resolution or motion.
Section 3.13 Ordinances in General.
   (a)   Form. Every proposed ordinance shall be introduced in writing and in
the form required for final adoption. No ordinance shall contain more than one
subject which shall be clearly expressed in its title. The enacting clause
shall be “Hanover Township hereby ordains...” Any ordinance which repeals or
amends an existing ordinance or part of the Township Administrative Code shall
set out in full the ordinance, sections or subsections to be repealed or
amended, and shall indicate matter to be omitted by enclosing it in brackets or
by strikeout type and shall indicate new matter by underscoring or by italics.
   (b)   Procedure. An ordinance may be introduced by any member at any regular
or special meeting of the council or by the initiative procedure. Upon
introduction of any ordinance, the Township clerk shall distribute a copy to
each council member and to the manager, shall file a reasonable number of
copies in the office of the Township clerk and such other public places as the
council may designate, and shall publish within seven (7) days the ordinance or
summary thereof together with a notice setting out the time and place for a
public hearing thereon for its consideration by the council. The public hearing
shall follow the publication by at least seven (7) days, may be a regular or a
special council meeting and may be adjourned from time to time; all persons
interested shall have an opportunity to be heard. After the hearing, the
council may adopt the ordinance with or without amendment or reject it but, if
it is amended as to any matter of substance, the council may not adopt it until
the ordinance or its amended sections have been subjected to all the procedures
hereinbefore required in the case of a newly introduced ordinance. As soon as
practicable after adoption of any ordinance, the clerk shall have it published
again together with a notice of its adoption.
   (c)   Effective Date. Except as otherwise provided in this charter, every
adopted ordinance shall become effective at the expiration of 30 days after
adoption or at any later date specified therein.
   (d)   “Publish” Defined. As used in this section, the term “publish” means
to post on the Township’s internet website: (1) the ordinance or a brief
summary thereof; (2) the name and vote case of each council member; and (3) the
places where copies of it have been filed and the times when they are available
for public inspection. Notice of a hearing shall remain posted until the
hearing is concluded. An adopted ordinance shall remain posted until repealed
or posted in codified form. Such publication is in addition to any other
publication required by law. 8
 
Notes
8    Amended by Section 8 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by Referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 3.14 Emergency Ordinances.
To meet a public emergency imminently affecting life, health, property or the
public peace, the council may adopt one or more emergency ordinances, but such
ordinances may not levy taxes, grant, renew or extend a franchise, regulate the
rate charged by any public utility for its services or authorize the borrowing
of money except as provided in subsection 7.09 (a). An emergency ordinance
shall be introduced in the form and manner prescribed for ordinances generally,
except that it shall be plainly designated as an emergency ordinance and shall
contain, after the enacting clause, a declaration stating that an emergency
exists and describing it in clear and specific terms. An emergency ordinance
may be adopted with or without amendment or rejected at the meeting at which it
is introduced, but the affirmative vote of a majority of council members shall
be required for adoption. After its adoption the ordinance shall be published
and printed as prescribed for other adopted ordinances. It shall become
effective upon adoption or at such later time as it may specify. Every
emergency ordinance except one made pursuant to subsection 7.09(a) shall
automatically stand repealed as of the 61st day following the date on which it
was adopted, but this shall not prevent re- enactment of the ordinance in the
manner specified in this section if the emergency still exists. An emergency
ordinance may also be repealed by adoption of a repealing ordinance in the same
manner specified in this section for adoption of emergency ordinances.
Section 3.15 Codes of Technical Regulations.
The council may adopt any standard code of technical regulations by reference
thereto in an adopting ordinance. The procedure and requirements governing such
an adopting ordinance shall be as prescribed for ordinances generally except
that:
   (1)   The requirements of Section 3.13 for distribution and filing of copies
of the ordinance shall be construed to include copies of the code of technical
regulations as well as of the adopting ordinance, and,
   (2)   A copy of each adopted code of technical regulations as well as of the
adopting ordinance shall be authenticated and recorded by the Township clerk
pursuant to subsection 3.16(a).
Copies of any adopted code of technical regulations shall be made available by
the Township clerk for distribution or for purchase by the public at a
reasonable price.
Section 3.16 Authentication and Recording; Codification; Printing.
   (a)   Authentication and Recording. The Township clerk shall within 30 days
after adopting authenticate by his/her signature all ordinances and resolutions
adopted by council. He/she shall also:
      1.   Record the full text of all ordinances and resolutions adopted by
council in a properly indexed book which shall be maintained in the Township
building at all times, and
      2.   Record the full text of all ordinances and resolutions adopted by
the council and having the force and effect of law. 9
   (b)   Codification. Within three years after adoption of this charter and at
least every ten years thereafter, the council shall provide for the preparation
of a general codification of all Township ordinances and resolutions having the
force and effect of law. The General codification shall be adopted by the
council by ordinance and shall be published promptly in bound or loose- leaf
form, together with this charter and any amendments thereto, pertinent
provisions of the Constitution and other laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylva
nia, and such codes of technical regulations and other rules and regulations as
the council shall specify. This compilation shall be known and cited officially
as the Statutory Code of Hanover Township, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania. Copies
of the Code shall be furnished to Township officers, placed in libraries and
public offices for free public reference and made available for purchase by the
public at a reasonable price fixed by the council.
   (c)   Printing of Ordinances and Resolutions. The council shall cause each
ordinance and resolution having the force and effect of law and each amendment
to this charter to be printed promptly following to adoption, and the printed
ordinances, resolutions and charter amendments, shall be distributed or sold to
the public at reasonable prices to be fixed by the council. Following
publication of the first Statutory Code of Hanover Township, Lehigh County,
Pennsylvania and at all times thereafter, the ordinances, resolutions, and
charter amendments shall be printed in substantially the same style as the
Statutory Code in effect and shall be suitable in form for integration therein.
The council may make such further arrangements as it deems desirable with
respect to reproduction and distribution of any current changes in or additions
to the provisions of the Constitution and other laws of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylva nia, or the codes of technical regulations and other rules and
regulations included in the Code.
 
Notes
9    Amended by Section 9 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by Referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 3.17 Enforcement of Ordinances.
   (a)   All proceedings for the violation of any ordinances and for the
recovery of fines or penalties imposed thereby shall be brought as prescribed
by law or Township ordinance or the Township Administrative Code.
   (b)   The penalty for the violation of any ordinance shall not exceed the
maximum amount permitted by law for each violation, or thirty (30) days
imprisonment in default of payment of fine. Any ordinance may provide that for
continuing violations, each day that a violation exists may be regarded as a
separate offense and punishable as such. The council by ordinance may increase
the penalty to the extent permissible under general municipal law including
non- home rule charter municipalities. 10
 
Notes
10    Amended by Section 10 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by Referendum at the
   November 4, 2014, General Election.
Article IV
Township Manager
Section 4.01 Appointment; Qualifications; Compensation.
   (a)   Appointment. The council shall appoint by an affirmative vote of a
majority of all its members a Township manager for an indefinite term; however,
by mutual agreement, the council and manager may fix the term by contract.
   (b)   Qualifications. The manager shall be: (1) a college graduate,
preferably with a degree in political science, public or municipal administra
tion, or some related field, and shall have at least two (2) years experience
as an intern in municipal management, an assistant municipal manager, or
municipal manager, or any combination thereof; or (2) a professional manager
with a minimum of five (5) years experience and active as a municipal manager
within the last year. He/she need not be a resident of the Township at the time
of his/her appointment or during his/her term of office, but he/she shall live
within a ten (10) mile radius of the Township during his/her term of office.
   (c)   Compensation. The council shall fix the manager’s compensation by
resolution. Such compensation shall be commensurate with the compensation
provided to other municipal managers with similar administrative responsibili
ties.
Section 4.02 Removal.
The council may remove the manager from office in accordance with the following
procedures:
      (1)   The council shall adopt by affirmative vote of a majority of all
its members a preliminary resolution which must state the reasons for removal
and may suspend the manager from duty for a period not to exceed 45 days. A
copy of the resolution must be delivered promptly to the manager.
      (2)   Within five (5) days after a copy of the resolution is delivered to
the manager, he/she may file with the council a written request for a public
hearing. This hearing shall be held at a special council meeting not earlier
than fifteen (15) days nor later than thirty (30) days after the request is
filed. The manager may file with the council a written reply not later than
five (5) days before the hearing.
      (3)   The council may adopt a final resolution of removal, which may be
made effective immediately, by affirmative vote of a majority of all its
members at any time after five (5) days from the date when a copy of the
preliminary resolution was delivered to the manager, if he/she has not
requested a public hearing, or at any time after the public hearing if he/she
has requested one. The manager shall continue to receive his/her salary until
the effective date of a final resolution of removal, at which time he/she also
shall receive a severance pay equivalent to two (2) months salary. The
severance pay shall not be applicable in the case of defalcation by the
manager. 1
 
Notes
1    Amended by Section 11 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by Referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 4.03 Vacancy.
Any vacancy in the office of Township manager shall be filled within five (5)
months after the effective date of such vacancy. In the event of permanent or
indefinite absence or disability of the Township manager, the council shall, by
resolution, declare the office of Township manager vacant. Council shall then
appoint a person to serve as interim Township manager until such time, not to
exceed six (6) months, as a permanent Township manager is appointed in
accordance with the provisions of Article IV.
As interim manager, he/she shall be responsible for all duties assigned to the
manager by this charter. *
 
Notes
*    Last three sentences added by approval of the electorate in the May 15,
  1979 Primary Election.
Section 4.04 Acting Township Manager.
By letter filed with the Township clerk, the manager shall designate, subject
to approval of the council, a Township administrative officer to exercise the
powers and perform the duties of manager during his/her temporary absence or
disability. During such absence or disability, the council may revoke such
designation at any time and appoint another officer of the Township to serve
until the manager shall return or his/her disability shall cease.
Section 4.05 Powers and Duties.
The Township manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the Township.
He/she shall be responsible to the council for the administration of all
Township affairs placed in his/her charge by or under this charter. He/she
shall have the following powers and duties:
   (1)   He/she shall appoint and, when he/she deems it necessary, may suspend
or remove any Township employees and appointive administrative officers
provided for by or under this charter, except as otherwise provided by law,
this charter, or personnel rules adopted pursuant to this charter. He/she may
authorize any administrative officer who is subject to his/her direction and
supervision to exercise these powers with respect to subordinates in that
officer’s department, office, or agency.
   (2)   He/she shall direct and supervise the administration of all
departments, offices, and agencies of the Township, except as otherwise
provided by this charter or by law.
   (3)   He/she shall attend council meetings and shall have the right to take
part in discussion but may not vote.
   (4)   He/she shall see that all laws, provisions of this charter, and acts
of the council, subject to enforcement by him/her or by officers subject to
his/her direction and supervision, are faithfully executed.
   (5)   He/she shall have responsibility for preparation and presentation of
the capital programs and the proposed budget to council. He/she shall have
direct responsibility for the administration of the council approved budget.
   (6)   He/she shall submit to the council and make available to the public a
complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the Township
at the end of each fiscal year.
   (7)   He/she shall make such other reports as the council may require
concerning the operations of Township departments, offices, agencies subject to
his/her direction and supervision.
   (8)   He/she shall keep the council fully advised as to the financial
condition and future needs of the Township and make such recommendations to the
council concerning the affairs of the Township as he/she deems desirable.
   (9)   He/she shall be responsible for the disbursement of all Township funds
authorized by the council through a voucher system detailing individual
expenditures.
   (10)   He/she shall perform such other duties as are specified in this
charter or may be required by the council in written instructions.
Section 4.06 Emergency Powers.
In event of an emergency imminently affecting life, or the public peace, the
Township manager may award interim contracts and make purchases for the purpose
of meeting said emergency. Such purchases and contracts may be made
notwithstanding the requirements of subsection 7.10(b), and those of Article
VIII, sections 8.01, 8.02, 8.03 and 8.04. However, upon making such purchases
and/or entering into such contracts, the Township manager shall call for an
emergency meeting of the Township council in accordance with subsection 3.10(a)
for the purpose of making emergency appropriations. As soon as practicable, the
manager shall file in writing with the council a certificate clearly describing
the emergency and the necessity for such action, together with an itemized
account of all expenditures.
Article V
Administrative Departments and Offices
Section 5.01 General Provisions.
   (a)   Creation of Departments. The council may establish Township
departments, offices or agencies in addition to those created by this charter
and may prescribe the functions of all departments, offices, and agencies,
except that no function assigned by this charter to a particular department,
office or agency may be discontinued or assigned to any other department,
office or agency unless this charter specifically so provides.
   (b)   Direction by Manager. All departments, offices and agencies under the
direction and supervision of the manager shall be administered by an officer
appointed by and subject to the direction and supervision of the manager. With
the consent of the council, the manager may serve as the head of one or more
such departments, offices or agencies or may appoint one person as the head of
two or more departments, offices or agencies.
Section 5.02 Personnel System.
   (a)   Merit Principle. All appointments and promotions of Township officers
and employees shall be made solely on the basis of merit and fitness
demonstrated by examination or other evidence.
   (b)   Personnel Director. The Township manager shall be the personnel
director and he/she shall administer the personnel system of the Township.
   (c)   Personnel Board. There shall be a personnel board consisting of three
members appointed by the council for terms of three (3) years from among the
qualified voters of the Township. Township employees may not be members of the
personnel board. The personnel director shall provide necessary staff
assistance for the personnel board.
   (d)   Personnel Rules. The Township manager shall prepare personnel rules.
The manager shall refer such proposed rules to the personnel board which shall
report to the manager its recommendations thereon. When approved by the
manager, the rules shall be proposed to the council to be adopted by ordinance.
These rules shall provide for:
      (1)   The classification of all Township positions, based on the duties,
authority and responsibility of each position, with adequate provision for
reclassification of any position whenever warranted by changed circumstances;
      (2)   A pay plan for all Township positions;
      (3)   Methods for determining the merit and fitness of candidates for
appointment or promotion;
      (4)   The policies and procedures regulating reduction in force and
removal of employees;
      (5)   The hours of work, attendance regulations and provisions for sick
and vacation leave;
      (6)   The policies and procedures governing persons holding provisional
appointments;
      (7)   The policies and procedures governing relationships with employee
organizations;
      (8)   Policies regarding in-service training programs;
      (9)   Grievance procedures, including procedures for the hearing of
grievances by the personnel board, which may render advisory opinions based on
its findings to the Township manager with a copy to the aggrieved employee; and
      (10)   Other practices and procedures necessary to the administra tion of
the Township personnel system.
Section 5.03 Township Attorney.
There shall be a Township attorney, learned in the law with at least five years
experience in active legal practice who shall have been admitted to practice
before the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. He/she shall be
appointed by the manager with the consent of council and shall serve as chief
legal adviser to the council, the manager and all Township departments, offices
and agencies. The Township attorney shall represent the Township in all legal
proceedings and shall perform any other duties prescribed by this charter. With
the approval of the council, the Township attorney may retain special counsel
for a particular proceeding.
Section 5.04 Township Engineer.
There shall be a Township engineer appointed by the manager with the consent of
the council. The Township engineer, or representative thereof, shall be a
professional engineer registered in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and shall
have all other qualifications as may be mandated by state or federal law. The
Township engineer shall serve as chief engineering adviser to the council, the
manager, and all Township departments, offices, and agencies, and shall
represent the Township in all engineering matters.
Section 5.05 Township Treasury Department.
A Township treasury department shall be established under the direction and
supervision of the Township manager. This department shall have the following
powers, duties, and authority:
   (a)   To receive, collect, account for, and deposit into the Township
treasury, all taxes, fees, funds, assessments or charges that are levied,
established or received by the Township for general or special purposes. Such
deposits shall be made not later than the first business day following the day
in which the funds are received.
   (b)   To disburse Township funds pursuant to authorization for payment made
by the council.
   (c)   To arrange for temporary investments of Township funds and to make
such investments as directed by ordinance.
   (d)   To deposit the funds of the Township in various depositories as
designated by the council. All such accounts shall be in the name of the
Township.
   (e)   To monthly state the accounts, and lay the same, together with the
books and the vouchers, before the council for audit.
   (f)   The acting Township manager as appointed pursuant to Section 4.04
shall sign checks or drafts of the Township during any absence or disability of
the Township manager.
   (g)   With the approval of Council and as permitted by law, to authorize a
public or private entity or entities to perform some or all of the functions
designated in paragraph (a), above, and, with respect to monies collected, make
temporary deposit in the depositories of any such entity; provided, any such
entity shall post a bond of a corporate surety in an amount no less than the
collections that may be in possession of the entity at any time or as otherwise
provided by law. 1
 
Notes
     Editor’s Note: Section 5.05(g) added by approval of the referendum question by
1 the voters at the General Election held November 8, 2011, of the amendment proposed
  to the Home Rule Charter by Ord. 521, 7/20/2011.
Section 5.06 Township Clerk.
The Township manager shall employ a person who shall have the title of Township
clerk. The Township clerk shall give notice of council meetings to its members
and public, keep the journal of its proceedings and perform such other duties
as are assigned to him/her by this charter or by the Township manager.
Section 5.07 Public Documents.
Every elected official, officer or employee of the Township shall upon ceasing
to hold office or employment deliver to his/her successor or agency head or to
the Township clerk all books, correspondence, documents, papers, pamphlets,
models, pictures, plans, photographs, plats, maps, films, seals and other
objects or materials prepared for or originated by such elected official,
officer, or employee in connection with the transaction of business during the
period when such individual held office or employment and which would not have
been prepared if that individual had not held such office.
Article VI
Personnel Provisions
Section 6.01 Official Bonds.
The Township manager, acting Township manager and the Township clerk, before
entering upon their duties, and such other employees as the Township council
may designate, shall give and acknowledge to the Township fidelity and surety
bonds issued by corporate sureties authorized and licensed to do business in
Pennsylvania. All such bonds and corporate sureties thereon before being
accepted by the Township shall be approved by the Township attorney.
The Township shall pay for all premiums for official bonds. The Township
manager shall be the custodian of all such bonds except that of his/her own
which shall be held by the Township clerk.
Section 6.02 Oath of Office.
The councilmen, members of board, commissions, the Township manager, the
Township attorney, the Township clerk, department and bureau heads, directors
and such other officers and employees as the council may by ordinance
determine, prior to assuming office, shall take and shall sign an oath of
office as shall from time to time be prescribed by the laws of the Commonwealth
of Pennsylvania. Such an oath may be taken and signed before any district
magistrate of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and written form is filed with
the Township clerk.
Section 6.03 Conflicts of Interest.
   (a)   Declaration of Intent. The purpose of this section is to prevent
elected officials, officers, and employees from securing any financial benefits
from their public positions other than their compensation provided by law or by
this charter.
   (b)   All officials, officers and employees shall abide by all applicable
provisions of the Pennsylvania Public Official and Employee Ethics Act, as it
may be amended. 1
   (c)   Specific Prohibition. No elected official, officer, or employee in
his/her official capacity shall participate in the consideration or approval of
any Township business in which he/she has a direct or indirect financial
interest.
   (d)   Disclosure. Any elected official, officer, or employee, who is aware
that he/she has ownership or any interest in any person, firm, or corporation
dealing or doing business with the Township, shall disclose such interest by
sending a letter setting forth such facts to the Township clerk who shall
distribute copies of the letter to the members of the Township council.
   (e)   Action. The Township council shall determine whether a conflict
exists. If a conflict exists as to a member of the Township council, that
member shall not participate in debate or vote on the matter. The Township
council and the Township manager jointly and severally, shall have the power to
void any contract made in violation of this subsection.
 
Notes
1    Amended by Section 12 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by Referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 6.04 Soliciting of Employment Favors.
No individual who seeks promotion or appointment with respect to any position
or office shall directly or indirectly give, render, or pay any money, service,
or other valuable thing to any person for or in connection with his/her past
appointment, proposed appointment, promotion, or proposed promotion.
Section 6.05 Private Use of Public Employees or Property.
No elected official, officer, or employee of the Township shall direct or
compel any other elected official, officer, or employee of the Township to do
or perform any private service work outside of his/her public office or
employment. No elected official, officer, or employee shall perform any such
work during the hours he/she is performing as a Township employee; nor shall
any elected official, officer, or employee use or devote any Township owned
property for any private purpose other than that for the benefit of the
Township.
Section 6.06 Penalty for Violation of Charter.
Any elected official, officer, or employee who knowingly and willfully violates
any of the provisions of this charter shall be dismissed from his/her office or
employment.
Section 6.07 Political Activity.
   (a)   Each compensated Township official, officer, or employee may
participate or refrain from participating in political activity but no
compensated Township official, officer, or employee shall engage in political
activity while performing the duties of his/her position with the Township or
service as a Township committee person of a political party.
   (b)   No elected official, officer, or employee in any way shall solicit any
assessment, subscription, or contribution for any political party,
organization, committee, or candidate from any compensated officer or Township
employee.
Section 6.08 Activities Prohibited.
   (a)   No person shall be appointed to or removed from, or in any way favored
or discriminated against with respect to any Township position or appointive
Township administrative office because of race, sex, political or religious
opinions or affiliations.
   (b)   No person shall willfully make any false statement, certificate, mark,
rating or report in regard to any test, certification or appointment under the
personnel provisions of this charter or the rules and regulations made
thereunder, or in any manner commit or attempt to commit any fraud preventing
the impartial execution of such provisions, rules and regulations.
Section 6.09 Penalties.
Any person who by himself or with others willfully violated any of the
provisions of sections 6.04, 6.07, 6.08, or 6.09 shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punishable under the
provisions of the Crimes Code of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania or succeeding
Pennsylvania criminal law. Any person convicted under this section shall be
ineligible for a period of five years thereafter to hold any Township office or
position and, if an elected official, officer, or employee of the Township,
shall immediately forfeit his/her office or position. 2
 
Notes
2    Amended by Section 2 of Ord. 550, 12/8/2013, approved by Referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Article VII
Financial Procedures
Section 7.01 Fiscal Year.
The fiscal year of the Township shall begin on the first day of January and end
on the last day of December.
Section 7.02 Capital Program.
   (a)   Submission to Council. The manager shall prepare and submit to the
council a five year capital program at least three months prior to the final
date for submission of the budget.
   (b)   Contents. The capital program shall include:
      1.   A clear general summary of its contents;
      2.   A list of all capital improvements which are proposed to be
undertaken during the five fiscal years next ensuing, with appropriate
supporting information as to the necessity for such improvements;
      3.   Cost estimates, method of financing and recommended time schedules
for each such improvement; and
      4.   The estimated annual cost of operating and maintaining the
facilities to be constructed or acquired.
   The above information may be revised and extended each year with regard to
capital improvements still pending or in process of construction or
acquisition.
Section 7.03 Council Action on Capital Program.
   (a)   Notice and Hearing. Not more than fifteen (15) days after receipt of
the capital program from the manager, the council shall publish in one or more
newspapers of general circulation in the Township the general summary of the
capital program and a notice stating:
      1.   The times and places where copies of the capital program are
available for inspection by the public, and
      2.   The time and place, not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than
thirty (30) days after such publication, for a public hearing on the capital
program.
   (b)   Amendment Before Adoption. The council may amend the capital program.
Any amendment to the capital program shall be made at the public hearing and
shall require an affirmative vote of a simple majority of the council members.
   (c)   Adoption. The council by resolution shall adopt the capital program,
as amended, after the public hearing but prior to adoption of the budget for
the ensuing year, and no later than the fifteenth day of September of the
current fiscal year.
Section 7.04 Work Program.
At such time as the manager shall specify, but prior to submission of the
budget message, each department, office, or agency shall submit to the manager
written proposed work programs for the ensuing fiscal year. The manager shall
use these proposals as guidelines when preparing the budget and he/she may
revise them at his/her discretion.
Section 7.05 Submission of Proposed Budget and Budget Message.
On or before the first day of October of each year, the manager shall submit to
the council a proposed budget for the ensuing year and an accompanying message.
Section 7.06 Budget Message.
The manager’s message shall explain the budget both in fiscal terms and in
terms of the work programs. It shall outline the proposed financial policies of
the Township for the ensuing fiscal year, describe the important features of
the budget, indicate any major changes from the current year in financial
policies, expenditures, and revenues together with the reasons for such
changes, summarize the Township’s debt position and include such other material
as the manager deems desirable.
Section 7.07 Budget.
The budget shall provide a complete financial plan of all Township funds and
activities for the ensuing fiscal year and, except as required by law or by
this charter, shall be in such a form as the manager deems desirable or the
council may require. In organizing the budget, the manager shall utilize the
most feasible combination of expenditure classification by fund, organization
unit, program, purpose or activity, and object. It shall begin with a clear
general summary of its content; shall show in detail all estimated collectable
income, indicating the proposed property tax levy, and all proposed
expenditures, including debt service for the ensuing fiscal year, and shall be
so arranged as to show comparative figures for actual and estimated collectable
income and expenditures of the preceding fiscal year. It shall indicate in
separate sections:
   (a)   Proposed expenditures for current operations for the ensuing fiscal
year, detailed by offices, departments, and agencies in terms of their
respective work programs, and the method of financing such expenditures;
   (b)   Proposed capital expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year, detailed by
offices, departments, and agencies where practicable, and the proposed method
of financing each capital expenditure; and
   (c)   Anticipated net surplus or deficit for the ensuing fiscal year for
each utility owned or operated by the Township and the proposed method of its
disposition; subsidiary budgets for each such utility giving detailed income
and expenditure information shall be attached as appendices to the budget.
   (d)   Surplus Funds. The total or proposed expenditures shall equal the
total of estimated collectable income. Any excess income collected during the
fiscal year shall be treated as surplus funds. Surplus funds shall be placed in
interest bearing escrow accounts until the next following fiscal year. These
funds shall then be incorporated into the budget, having the net effect of
reducing the proposed tax levy. However, such surplus funds may be utilized
during the year in which they are collected to satisfy any emergency appropria
tions made pursuant to Section 7.09(a).
Section 7.08 Council Action on Budget.
   (a)   Notice and Hearing. Not more than fifteen (15) days after receipt of
the proposed budget from the manager, the council shall publish in one or more
newspapers of general circulation in the Township the general summary of the
budget and a notice stating:
      1.   The times and places where copies of the message and budget are
available for inspection by the public, and
      2.   The time and place, not less than ten (10) days nor more than twenty
(20) days after such publication, for a public hearing on the budget.
   (b)   Amendment Before Adoption. Within ten (10) days after the public
hearing, the council may amend the budget. In amending the budget, it may
increase programs or amounts and may delete or decrease any programs or
amounts, except expenditures required by law or for debt service or for
estimated cash deficit, provided that no amendment to the budget shall increase
the authorized expenditures to an amount greater than the total of estimated
collectable income. Any proposed amendment shall be introduced by resolution.
An affirmative vote by a simple majority of the council members shall
constitute acceptance of the amendment of the council.
   (c)   Submission of Amendment to Manager. Upon acceptance of any amendment
by the council, the manager shall within three (3) days receive a written copy
of the amendment. Within ten (10) days after receipt, the manager shall return
the amendment to the council with a written opinion related to the amendment.
   (d)   Notice and Hearing for Budget Amendment. A public hearing shall be
held on all budget amendments, if any, prior to adoption of the budget. The
council, within three (3) days after the return of all budget amendments from
the manager, shall publish in one or more newspapers of general circulation in
the Township the budget amendment(s), and a notice stating the time and place,
not less than seven (7) days nor more than fifteen (15) days after such
publication, for the public hearing on these amendments.
   (e)   Adoption of Budget; Appropriation and Tax Levy Ordinances. The council
shall adopt the budget on or before the fifteenth day of December of the fiscal
year currently ending. Adoption of the budget shall constitute adoption of an
ordinance appropriating the amounts specified therein from the funds indicated
and an ordinance levying the property tax therein proposed. The effective date
of the ordinances shall be the first day of January following adoption.
Section 7.09 Amendments after Adoption.
   (a)   Emergency Appropriations. To meet a public emergency affecting life,
health, property, or the public peace, the council may make emergency
appropriations. Such appropriations may be made by emergency ordinance in
accordance with the provisions of Section 3.14. To the extent that there are no
unappropriated revenues to meet such appropriations, the council may by such
emergency ordinance authorize the issuance of emergency notes, which may be
renewed from time to time, but the emergency notes and renewals of any fiscal
year shall be paid not later than the last day of the fiscal year next
succeeding that in which the emergency appropriation was made.
   (b)   Reduction of Appropriations. If at any time during the fiscal year it
appears probable to the manager that the revenues available will be
insufficient to meet the amount appropriated, he/she shall report to the
council without delay, indicating the estimated amount of the deficit, any
remedial action taken by him/her and his/her recommendations as to any other
steps to be taken. The council shall then take such action as it deems
necessary to prevent or minimize any deficit and for that purpose it shall have
the power by ordinance to reduce one or more appropriations.
   (c)   Transfer of appropriations. After the first day of September of the
current fiscal year the manager may transfer part or all of any unencumbered
appropriation balance among programs within a department, office, or agency
and, upon written request by the manager, the council may by resolution
transfer part or all of any unencumbered appropriation balance from one
department, office, or agency to another, provided that such transfer does not
exceed 5% of the total adopted budget. Any transfer in excess of 5% shall be by
ordinance.
   (d)   Limitations; Effective Date. No appropriation for debt service may be
reduced or transferred, and no appropriation may be reduced below any amount
required by law to be appropriated or by more than the amount of any
unencumbered balance thereof. Emergency appropriations and reduction or
transfer of appropriations authorized by this section may be made effective
immediately upon adoption of the required ordinance.
   (e)   After the adoption of the budget, if projected revenue and other funds
available for appropriation result in a projected surplus, any tax of the
Township may be reduced or repealed consistent with the requirements of Section
7.07(d) of this Charter. *
 
Notes
*    Added by approval of the electorate in the November 4, 1980, General
  Election.
Section 7.10 Administration of Budget.
   (a)   Work Programs and Allotments. At such time as the manager shall
specify, each department, office, or agency shall submit a schedule for the
ensuing fiscal year showing the requested allotments of its appropriation by
periods within the year for each work program. The manager shall review and
authorize such allotments with or without revision as early as possible in the
fiscal year. He/she may revise such allotments during the year if necessary and
shall revise them with respect to any emergency, reduced, or transferred
appropriations made pursuant to Section 7.09.
   (b)   Payments and Obligations Prohibited. No payment shall be made or
obligation incurred against any allotment or appropriation except in accordance
with appropriations duly made and unless the manager or his/her designee first
certifies that there is a sufficient unencumbered balance in such allotment or
appropriation and that sufficient funds therefrom are or will be available to
cover the claim or meet the obligation when it becomes due and payable. Any
authorization of payment or incurring of obligation in violation of the
provisions of this charter shall be void and any payment so made illegal; such
action shall be cause for removal of any officer who knowingly authorized or
made such payment or incurred such obligation, and he/she shall also be liable
to the Township for any amount so paid. However, except where prohibited by
law, nothing in this charter shall be construed to prevent the making or
authorizing of payments and making of contracts for capital improvements to be
financed wholly or partly by the issuance of bonds or notes or to prevent the
making of any contract or lease providing for payments beyond the end of the
fiscal year, provided that such contract or lease was provided for in the
budget as adopted and that such action is made or approved by ordinance.
Section 7.11 Lapse of Appropriations.
Every appropriation, except an appropriation for a capital expenditure, shall
lapse at the close of the fiscal year to the extent that it has not been
expended or encumbered. An appropriation for a capital expenditure shall
continue in force until the purpose for which it was made has been accomplished
or terminated. Any appropriation for a capital project which is terminated or
abandoned shall be treated as surplus funds pursuant to Section 7.07(d). Any
appropriation for a capital expenditure shall lapse when the purpose of which
the appropriation is made is removed from the capital program of the Township.
*
 
Notes
*    Last sentence amended by approval of the electorate in the November 4,
  1980, General Election.
Section 7.12 Public Records.
Copies of the budget and the capital program as adopted shall be made available
to the public at the Township municipal building and any other places deemed
suitable.
Section 7.13 Township Debt Limitation.
The Township shall be subject to the provisions of the Pennsylvania Local
Government Unit Debt Act (Act 185 of 1972) as amended.
Article VIII
Contracts
Section 8.01 Requirements.
All contracts or purchases of the Township involving sums in excess of One
Thousand Five Hundred ($1,500.00) Dollars shall be in writing and shall be
executed on behalf of the Township by the Township manager. The Township
manager shall also execute all contracts, regardless of amount, for the
purchase, sale, leasing, or use of real estate with approval of the council.
Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, the Township manager may execute
contracts or make purchases on behalf of the Township involving sums of less
than One Thousand Five Hundred ($1,500.00) Dollars. Authorization for contracts
for the construction of public capital improvements shall be given by ordinance
only, regardless of the amount involved. The Township manager, when required to
execute a written contract, shall request the Township attorney to approve the
same as to form.
Section 8.02 Competitive Bids.
Except as otherwise provided in this charter, no contract for supplies,
material, labor, franchise, or other valuable consideration, to be furnished to
or by the Township, shall be authorized on behalf of the Township except with
the lowest responsible bidder after competitive bidding. All specifications
shall be written so as to be applicable to more than one supplier.
Section 8.03 Bidding Procedure. 1
The Council shall, by ordinance:
   (a)   Establish for contracts and purchases a system of competitive bidding,
including such definitions, publication requirements, deposit and bond
requirements, conditions, terms, rules, regulations, waivers, and exceptions,
as it shall from time to time deem advisable;
   (b)   Establish for contracts and purchases which are exempt from
competitive bidding pursuant to Section 8.04(d) hereof, a system for receiving
and recording multiple price quotes for any such contract or purchase in an
amount in excess of Ten Thousand ($10,000) Dollars;
   (c)   Establish a system to make and publish the adjustments required by the
following sentence, including the designation of an appropriate index, the
method of calculation of adjustment, effective date of adjustments and other
appropriate terms. The dollar amount set forth in Sections 8.03 and 8.04(d)
hereof shall be adjusted annually by an amount reflecting the change in the
consumer price index. Council may adopt a CPI adjustment established and
published by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania which uses a base year of 2011 to
adjust such amounts.
 
Notes
     Editor’s Note: Section 8.03 amended by adding subsections (b) and (c) as
1 proposed by Ord. 533, 8/1/2012, and approval of the referendum question by the
  electorate in the November 6, 2012, General Election.
Section 8.04 Exceptions to Competitive Bidding.
Competitive bidding shall not be required under this charter for:
   (a)   Labor or services rendered by any Township employee.
   (b)   Labor, material, supplies, or service furnished by one Township
department to another Township department.
   (c)   Those where particular types, models, or pieces of new equipment,
articles, apparatus, appliances, vehicles, or parts thereof are desired which
are patented and available from only one source.
   (d)   Contracts for labor, material, supplies or services aggregating less
than Eighteen Thousand Five Hundred ($18,500) Dollars for the item in the year
supplied. 2
   (e)   Contracts secured by participation in Pennsylvania’s Cooperative
Purchasing Program. 3
   (e)   Contracts relating to the acquisition or use of real property.
   (f)   Contracts for professional or unique service.
   (g)   Contracts for emergency repair of public works of the Township.
   (h)   Contracts with other governmental entities, authorities, agencies, or
political subdivisions.
 
Notes
     Editor’s Note: Section 8.04(d) amended by approval of the referendum
2 question by the voters at the General Election held November 6, 2012, of the
  amendment proposed to the Home Rule Charter by Ord. 533, 8/1/2012.
3    Subsection (e) added by approval of the electorate in the May 15, 1990,
  Primary Election.
Section 8.05 Maximum Term of Certain Contracts.
   The term of contracts for the purchase of supplies shall not exceed one
year.
Article IX
Direct Citizen Participation 1
 
Notes
     Article IX was amended by Ord. 552, 12/18/2013, approved by referendum at
1 the November 4, 2014 General Election to remove all references to recall of
  elected officials.
Section 9.01 Initiative and Referendum.
   (a)   Reservation of Power. In accordance with the provisions of this
article, the registered voters of the Township shall have the power by
initiative to propose ordinances which shall then be accepted or rejected at
the polls; and by referendum to accept or reject at the polls ordinances
already adopted by council.
   (b)   Limitation of Power. The power of initiative and referendum shall not
extend to the budget or capital program, to the appropriation of money, to the
levy of taxes, or to the salaries of elected officials, officers, or employees
of the Township. The power of referendum shall not extend to any emergency
ordinance or to any ordinance concurrently proposed by initiative.
Section 9.02 Application for Petitions.
Any five (5) registered voters of the Township shall have the power to commence
the procedure for initiative or referendum by filing with the County Board of
Elections an application stating: their names and mailing addresses; that they
are registered voters of the Township; that they will constitute a petition
committee to be responsible for circulating the petition and for filing it in
proper form; and the mailing address to which all notices to the petition
committee shall be sent. In addition, an application for an initiative or
referendum petition shall state the full text of the ordinance to be enacted,
suspended, or repealed. Upon the filing of the application, the County Board of
Elections shall issue the petition forms to the petition committee.
Section 9.03 Petitions.
   (a)   Form and Content. All papers of a petition shall be uniform in size
and style and shall be assembled as one instrument for filing. Each signature
shall be executed in ink or indelible pencil and shall be followed by the
mailing address of the signer. An initiative or referendum petition shall
contain or have attached thereto throughout its circulation the full text of
the ordinance to be enacted, suspended or repealed. Any proposed initiative
ordinance shall contain only one subject, which shall be clearly expressed in
its title.
   (b)   Affidavit of Circulator. Each paper of a petition shall have attached
to it when filed an affidavit executed by the circulator thereof stating: that
he/she personally circulated the paper; the number of signatures thereon; that
all the signatures were affixed in his/her presence, that he/she believes them
to be the genuine signatures of the persons whose names they purport to be; and
that each signer, in the case of an initiative or referendum petition, had an
opportunity before signing to read the full text of the ordinance to be
enacted, suspended, or repealed.
   (c)   Signatures. Initiative and referendum petitions must be signed by
registered voters of the Township equal in number to at least fifteen (15%) of
the number of voters registered for the last election held in the Township. No
signature on an initiative petition shall be counted as valid which is dated
more than ninety (90) days prior to the date the petition is tendered for
filing. No signature on a referendum petition shall be counted as valid which
is dated more than thirty (30) days prior to the date the petition is tendered
for filing.
   (d)   Time for Filing Petitions. An initiative petition shall be void unless
it is filed with the County Board of Elections within ninety (90) days after
the County Board of Elections issued the petition forms to the petition
committee. A referendum petition shall be void unless it is filed with the
County Board of Elections within thirty (30) days after the date of enactment
of the ordinance to be suspended or repealed.
Section 9.04 Certification of Petitions.
   (a)   Determination by County Board of Elections. Within twenty (20) days
after the date of the filing of the petition, the County Board of Elections
shall examine the petition and shall determine whether it conforms to the
provisions of this article. If the County Board of Elections determine that the
petition conforms to the provisions of this article, it shall certify the
petition as conforming and shall submit it to the Township council, in the case
of an initiative or referendum petition, for further action. If the County
Board of Elections determines that the petition does not conform to the
provisions of this article, it shall certify the petition as not conforming and
shall return it to the petition committee by registered mail, with a statement
of the findings of fact to support its determination; such determination shall
not prohibit the filing of another petition for the same purpose.
   (b)   Judicial Review. Any determination by the County Board of Elections
that the petition does not conform to the provisions of this article shall be
subject to judicial review only if the petition committee shall apply to the
Court for judicial review within twenty (20) days after such determina tion. In
such cases the petition committee shall have standing to apply for judicial
review, and the Court shall have jurisdiction.
   (c)   Determination by Court. If the Court determines that the petition
conforms to the provisions of this article, it shall certify the petition as
conforming and shall submit it for further action consistent with such
determination. Upon the final determination that the petition does not conform
to the provisions of this article, the petition shall become void.
Section 9.05 Suspension of Ordinances.
Upon the filing with the County Board of Elections of a referendum petition,
the ordinance to which the referendum petition pertains shall be suspended from
taking effect. Such suspension shall terminate upon the final determination
that the referendum petition does not conform to the provisions of this
article, upon the repeal of the ordinance to which the referendum petition
pertains, or upon certification by the County Board of Elections of the results
of the election at which the registered voters of the Township have voted on
whether to repeal the ordinance to which the referendum petition pertains,
whichever is sooner.
Section 9.06 Action on Initiative and Referendum Petitions.
   (a)   Action by Township Council. Upon the final determination that the
initiative or referendum petition conforms to the provisions of this article,
the Township council promptly shall consider the ordinance to which the
petition pertains. If the proposed ordinance is not enacted without any change
in substance, within thirty (30) days after such final determination or, if the
ordinance to which a referendum petition pertains is not repealed within thirty
(30) days after such final determination, the Township clerk shall within five
(5) days thereafter file the petition with the County Board of Elections for
further action.
   (b)   Submission to Voters. After the Township Clerk files the petition with
the County Board of Elections, it shall cause the question as to whether the
ordinance to which the petition pertains be enacted or repealed to be placed on
the ballot, at the earliest general, municipal, or primary election to be held
in the Township at which the question may be considered in accordance with the
Pennsylvania Election Code. 2
 
Notes
2    Amended by Section 13 of Ord. 564, 7/22/2014, approved by referendum at the
  November 4, 2014, General Election.
Section 9.07 [Reserved].
Section 9.08 Elections.
   (a)   Initiative and Referendum. If a majority of the voters voting on a
proposed ordinance under initiative vote for its adoption, the proposed
ordinance shall be enacted upon certification of the results of the election.
If a majority of the voters voting on the repeal of an ordinance under
referendum vote for its repeal, the ordinance shall be repealed upon
certification of the results of the election.
   (b)   [Reserved].
   (c)   Results of Election. If conflicting ordinances are approved same
election, the one receiving the greatest number of affirmative votes shall
prevail to the extent of such conflict.
Section 9.09 Repeal and Amendment of Ordinances.
Any ordinance adopted or approved by the voters of the Township under this
article may not be amended or repealed by the council within one (1) year of
the effective date, except upon vote of the electorate. Any ordinance of the
council repealed through referendum shall not be re-enacted within one (1) year
of the referendum, except upon vote of the electorate under the initiative
procedures provided herein.
Article X
Transition
Section 10.01 Nature of Article.
The provisions of this article relate to the transition from the existing
commission form of government to the form of government provided in this
charter. Where inconsistent with the preceding articles of this charter, the
provisions of this article shall govern.
Section 10.02 Transition Procedure.
   (a)   On or before March 1, 1977, a transition committee consisting of five
(5) persons shall be appointed to draft necessary ordinances, rules and
regulations including the Administrative Code required by the charter in order
that they may be adopted by the Township council on or after the effective date
of this charter. The transition committee shall also assume the responsibility
of recruiting, interviewing and recommending candidates for the office of
Township manager. The transition committee shall include the two (2) Township
supervisors, who shall be incumbent supervisors at the effective date of the
charter, two (2) persons who were elected as members of the Township Government
Study Commission, and one (1) qualified elector appointed by elected members of
the Township Government Study Commission, the latter three (3) of whom shall
not be serving in any other Township government position. The two (2) members
of the transition committee who are elected members of the Township Government
Study Commission and the one (1) member of the transition committee who is the
qualified elector shall be replaced on the transition committee by the three
(3) members of the Township council elected by the qualified electors of the
Township in 1977 upon certification by the County Board of Elections of the
results of the election. Any vacancy on the transition committee among the
members from the Township Government Study Commission and the qualified elector
shall be filled by the remaining members of the transition committee.
   (b)   The Township Board of Supervisors in office in 1977 shall prepare and
adopt the budget for 1978, complying insofar as possible with the require ments
of Article VII of this charter.
      On or before the 15th day of January, 1978, the Township council may make
amendments to the budget. If amendments are proposed, a public hearing shall be
held on or before the 31st day of January, 1978. At least three (3) days prior
notice of such public hearing shall be given in at least one newspaper of
general circulation in the Township. The budget as amended shall be adopted
after the public hearing but in no case later than the 15th day of February,
1978. The amended budget as adopted shall be subject to the provisions of
Article VII in regard to its operation.
   (c)   A Township manager shall be appointed on or before April 1, 1978.
Until such time as a Township manager is appointed in accordance with the
provisions of Article IV, the Township council shall appoint a person to serve
as interim Township manager on or before January 15, 1978. As interim manager,
he/she shall be responsible for all duties assigned to the manager by this
charter.
   *Res. 1979-17 Declared the provisions of this article to be no longer
necessary.

PART 1
GENERAL AUTHORITY OF THE TOWNSHIP
§ 1-101.   Definitions.
The following words or phrases when used in this Part, shall have the meaning
ascribed to them in this Section unless the context clearly indicates
otherwise. Also, personal pronouns shall include the singular as well as the
plural number and the male, female and neuter gender.
   APPROPRIATE—means to set apart or assign Township fund to a particular
purpose or use in the annual budget.
   APPROPRIATION—means those Township funds that have been appropriated after
which such money is set aside by formal action for a specific use.
   BILL—means a proposed Ordinance introduced before Council.
   CHAIRMAN—means Chairman of Council, or in his absence, the Vice-Chairman of
Council.
   CHARTER—means the Home Rule Charter of Hanover Township, Lehigh County,
Pennsylvania.
   CITIZEN—means an individual who resides within the legal boundaries of
Hanover Township, Lehigh County.
   CLERK—means the Clerk of the Township; Township Clerk; Clerk of Council.
   CODE—means the Administrative Code of Hanover Township, Lehigh County,
Pennsylvania of February 14, 1979.
   COUNCIL—means the governing body of the Township as defined in Title Three.
   COUNCILMAN—means an elected or appointed member of the Township Council.
   COURT OF COMMON PLEAS—means the Court of Common Pleas of Lehigh County,
Pennsylvania.
   EMPLOYEE—means a Township employee who is employed by the Township for wages
or salary and in a position below the level of a legislative, executive or
professional person.
   ENCUMBERED—means funds of an appropriation which have been legally obligated
by means of contracts, payments due or upcoming or debt service.
   FULL-TIME EMPLOYEE—an employee who regularly works twenty (20) hours or more
per week. [Ord. 379]
   MANAGER—means the Administrative head of the Township as enumerated in
Article IV of the Charter.
   MOTION—means a proposal for formal action by Council on matters before
Council.
   OFFICER—means a representative of the Township who has been appointed to an
office as provided by law.
   OFFICIAL—means an elected representative of the Township which is enumerated
in the Charter.
   ORDINANCE—means a law set forth by the authority granted the Township which
applies to an order governing some detail of procedure or conduct enforced by
the authority of the municipality.
   PART-TIME EMPLOYEE—an employee other than a full-time employee. [Ord. 379]
   PERMANENT EMPLOYEE—an employee intended to be regularly employed as
determined in accordance with the Pennsylvania Municipal Retirement Law, Act 15
of 1974, which shall not include elected officials, employees hired on a
temporary or seasonal basis or individuals paid only on a fee bases. [Ord. 379]
   PERSON—means an individual, partnership, association, corporation or other
entity unless such a construction would be unreasonable.
   QUORUM—means any three of the five Council members.
   RESOLUTION—means a formal expression of an opinion, will, or intent of such
importance or length as to be in writing and for the purpose of the Charter
shall include a preamble setting forth the reasons for the opinion, will or
intent.
   STATE—means the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
   STATUTORY CODE—means a volume containing ordinances, resolutions and Charter
amendments of Hanover Township; which ordinances, resolutions and Charter
amendments have the force and effect of law.
   TAXPAYER—means any person who pays taxes to the Township as required by
Township ordinance.
   TOWNSHIP—means the Township of Hanover, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania.
   WORK PROGRAM—means a detailed written plan setting forth the objectives and
financial plan of each department, office or agency.
(Ord. 70 § 101, 2-14-79; as amended by Ord. 379, 2/3/1999, § 1)
