§ 1-314.   INVEST Program for Local Government.
   1.   Definitions.
      AGREEMENT—an intergovernmental cooperation agreement between the Township
and the Treasury Department of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania establishing
terms and conditions by which the Township may participate in the INVEST
Program.
      INVEST PROGRAM—the INVEST Program for Local Governments established by
the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania through which local
governments invest in the program and the pooled funds of local governments are
further managed and invested under the director of the State Treasurer.
      TOWNSHIP—Hanover Township, Lehigh County.
   2.   Pursuant to §
5.05(c) of the Hanover Township Charter, the Township Treasury Department is
authorized to purchase and redeem and otherwise invest in shares of the invest
program at the rate of $1 per share.
   3.   The State Treasurer shall serve as the investment manager of the
Township funds invested in and through the INVEST Program as more specifically
set forth in the agreement.
   4.   Any agreement shall be approved by resolution of the Township Council.
(Ord. 459, 6/1/2005)
PART 4
COUNCIL
§ 1-401.   General Powers and Duties.
All powers and duties of the Township Council shall be as provided in the
Charter.
(Ord. 70 § 3.04, 2-14-79)
§ 1-402.   Township Council - General.
The number of Council Members, their terms, election and qualifications and the
filing of Council vacancies shall be as provided in the Charter.
(Ord. 70 § 3.01, 2-14-79)
§ 1-403.   Compensation and Expenses.
The salary of Councilmen shall be $60 per meeting. Council shall determine
actual and necessary expenses upon submission of documented vouchers and shall
approve payment thereof.
(Ord. 70 § 3.02, 2-14-79; as amended by Ord. 241, 3/7/1990; and by Ord. 425, 6/
19/2002, § 1)
§ 1-404.   Officers of Council.
   1.   Election. The Chairman and Vice-Chairman shall be elected by an
affirmative roll call vote of the majority of Council.
   2.   Role of Chairman. In the absence of the Chairman, the Vice-Chairman
shall exercise the duties of the Chairman. In the absence of both the Chairman
and Vice-Chairman, the Council shall appoint a Chairman pro tem who shall have
all the powers of the Chairman.
   3.   Election of New Chairman. In the event of illness or absence of the
Chairman or Vice-Chairman for two or more consecutive meetings or sessions as
described in §
1-301 of this Code, the Council may by majority vote elect to declare the
respective position open and shall elect another member of Council to fill the
position.
(Ord. 70 § 3.03(c), 2-14-79; as amended by Ord. 547, 9/18/2013; and by Ord.
555, 2/5/2014)
§ 1-405.   Limitations on Attending Schools, Conventions or Seminars at
Township Expense.
Authorization to attend schools, conventions, seminars or similar functions at
Township expense shall be by motion of Council. The subject of such convention,
school or seminar and the reasons for attending shall be provided to Council
prior to approval for payment of expenses.
(Ord. 70 § 3.05, 2-14-79; as amended by Ord. 398, 10/4/2000)
§ 1-406.   Vacancies; Forfeiture of Office; Filling of Vacancies.
Vacancies, forfeiture of office and the filling of vacancies shall be as
provided in the Charter.
(Ord. 70 § 3.06, 2-14-79)
§ 1-407.   Forfeiture of Office; Judge of Its Members.
   1.   Complaint. A complaint constituting grounds for forfeiture of office of
any member of Council shall be submitted to the Township Manager by certified
letter at least 15 days prior to the next regularly scheduled Township meeting.
Such complaint shall include supporting evidence and must be filed by a
registered elector of the Township.
   2.   Formal Charges; Notification. If, by majority vote of Council members
present at the Township meeting, the complaint is accepted for further
consideration, charges shall be adopted by Council by resolution, and an
investigation shall be performed according to the provisions of the Charter.
Council shall notify the charged member by certified letter of the charges so
adopted.
   3.   Public Hearing. The charged member shall have 10 days from receipt of
the letter within which to submit a certified letter to the Manager demanding a
public hearing. If a public hearing is demanded, such hearing shall be held not
less than 15 days or more than 45 days from receipt of the letter of demand.
The provisions of Section
3.08 of the Charter shall apply to any such hearing.
   4.   Resolution of Council. The public hearing shall be concluded by Council
resolution determining whether or not the Council member shall forfeit his
office. If no public hearing is demanded, Council shall by resolution at its
next regularly scheduled meeting determine whether or not the Council member so
charged shall forfeit his office. Any such forfeiture shall be effective
immediately.
(Ord. 70 § 3.07, 2-14-79)
§ 1-408.   Council Investigations.
The Chairman and Vice-Chairman shall be empowered to administer any oaths to
witnesses as required by Council. The provisions of Section
3.08 of the Charter shall apply to all Council investigations.
(Ord. 70 § 3.08, 2-14-79)
§ 1-409.   Independent Audit.
   1.   Annual Audit. The annual audit as provided for in the Charter shall
include a complete and documented accounting and reconciliation of all Township
fiscal affairs. Such audit shall include a determination of compliance with the
accounting standards as provided in the Charter.
   2.   Financial Irregularities. All financial irregularities shall be
documented and shall be subject to Council investigation.
   3.   Submission of Annual Report. The annual audit report shall be submitted
by the designated accountant or firm to the Manager no later than 90 days after
the close of the fiscal year.
   4.   Interim Audits. Interim audits may be required by Council by
resolution. Such resolution shall detail the fiscal period to be audited, the
extent of the audit procedure, and the time limitation for submittal of the
interim audit report.
(Ord. 70 § 3.09(d), 2-14-79)
§ 1-410.   Meetings of Council
   1.   Generally Open to Public. All meetings of the Council, except as
otherwise provided, shall be open to the public and provisions governing public
notice and publication requirements shall be as provided by law.
   2.   Organization Meeting. The organization meeting of Council shall be held
at 7.30 p.m. in. the Township Municipal Building on the date as provided in the
Charter. The first order of business shall be the election of Chairman and
Vice-Chairman as provided in the Charter and this Code. Until the Chairman has
been elected, the Township Manager or his designee shall preside. The second
order of business shall be the appointment of other officers and officials as
required by law or as the Council may deem appropriate. The third order of
business shall be the designation of Township depositories by resolution. As
stated in the Charter, this meeting may be considered as a regular monthly
meeting for the transaction of such further business as may be presented.
   3.   Regular Meetings. It shall be the duty of Council to meet statedly as
required by the Charter and the Code. The Council may adjourn to a stated time
for general business or special business.
   4.   Special Meetings. Special meetings may be called by the Council
Chairman or upon the written request of three or more Council members. A
written notice shall be delivered to each Council member and public notice of
the meeting shall specify the time and place of the special meeting and the
business to be transacted. No other business shall be transacted at such
meeting by the Council. Presence at the meeting constitutes waiver of notice.
   5.   Emergency Meetings. Emergency meetings shall be called as provided for
in the Charter. The Council may take action at an emergency meeting at any time
provided that a quorum is present as required by the Charter and that a
majority of Council determine that the holding a meeting and the taking of
emergency action at that time is necessary to protect or promote the public
health and safety of the Township.
   6.   Executive Sessions. The Council may hold executive sessions as
permitted by law. However, no official action shall be taken by Council on any
matter in executive session.
   7.   Work Sessions. Work sessions may be scheduled upon written notice by
the Chairman or written request of three or more Council members. A copy of
such notice stating date, time and place of the work session(s) shall be
delivered to each Council member and conspicuously posted in the Township
Municipal Building. No further public notice or publication is required. No
official action shall be taken by Council on any matter at a work session.
(Ord. 70 § 3.10(a), 2-14-79)
§ 1-411.   Agenda.
   1.   Preparation.
      a.   Each Council Member and the Township Manager, Clerk, Engineer,
Attorney and any other Township official or employee shall advise the Township
Clerk by written or electronic communication of any subject on which he or she
may request Council deliberate or vote at least two days before the meeting of
Council at which such action is anticipated.
      b.   The proposed agenda and final agenda for any meeting of the Council
shall be prepared by the Manager in consultation with the Council Chairman and
shall include the subject of each matter on which it is anticipated that the
Council may deliberate or vote.
      c.   An abbreviated title of any bill, ordinance or resolution to be
considered shall be published as part of the proposed agenda and final agenda.
      d.   The proposed agenda may be amended at any time by the Township
Manager in consultation with the Council Chairman until the final agenda is
distributed by any of the methods in §
1-411(2)(b).
      e.   The final agenda shall be prepared by the Township Manager in
consultation with the Township Chairman at least 24 hours before the meeting.
   2.   Distribution.
      a.   The proposed agenda for any regular meeting shall be forwarded to
all members of Council and be available to the public at least 5 days prior to
said meeting.
      b.   The final agenda for regular, special and emergency meetings shall
be posted on the Township’s internet website at least 24 hours before the
convening of the meeting and, prior to the meeting, in the Township Municipal
Building and in the location in which Council is meeting if elsewhere.
      c.   Copies of the agenda shall be made available to individuals in
attendance at the meeting.
   3.   Amendment.
      a.   The final agenda may be amended at the meeting by a majority of the
members present and voting.
      b.   The reasons for the changes to the final agenda shall be announced
at the meeting before any vote is conducted to make the changes to the final
agenda.
      c.   If the final agenda is amended, the final agenda, as amended, shall
be posted in the Township Municipal Building and on the Township's internet
website no later than the first business day after the meeting at which the
agenda was changed.
   4.   This §
1-411 shall not apply to conferences, working sessions or executive sessions as
defined in the Pennsylvania Open Meetings Law.
(Ord. 70 § 3.10, 2-14-79; as amended by Ord. 635, 10-6-21)
§ 1-412.   Conduct of Business.
   1. Quorum Required. At the time appointed for any meeting of the Council,
the Chairman shall take the chair and call the meeting to order. If a quorum is
present, as provided in the Charter, the Chairman shall proceed with the order
of business prescribed for the meeting. If, upon the call of the roll, a quorum
is not present, the Chairman shall order a recess for a period of 15 minutes.
If a quorum has not developed by that time, prior to adjourning the meeting,
the Chairman shall instruct the Township Clerk to notify in writing those
members absent from said meeting of the time and place of the next scheduled
meeting of Council.
   2.   Usual Order of Business. Unless a majority of the Council votes
otherwise, the order of business for each regular meeting shall be as follows:
      A.   Call to Order.
      B.   Pledge of Allegiance.
      C.   Roll Call.
      D.   Opening of Bids (if applicable).
      E.   Approval of Minutes of the Previous Meeting(s).
      F.   Courtesy of the Floor.
      G.   Reports of Municipal Officials, Officers, Committees or Special
Advisory Groups.
      H.   Unfinished Business.
      I.   New Business.
      J.   Payment of Bills.
      K.   Courtesy of the Floor.
      L.   Adjournment.
   3.   Altering Order of Business. The Chairman of Council may alter the
sequence of items within any of the above categories at any time during the
meeting. However, the Chairman may be overruled by a majority of the Council
members present.
(Ord. 70, § 3.10(c), 2-14-79)
§ 1-413.   Rules of Procedure.
   1.   Duties of Chairman. The Chairman of Council shall be responsible for
the orderly conduct of business at each Council meeting and shall preserve
order and decorum at such meeting.
   2.   Announcing Decisions. The Chairman of Council shall announce all
decisions of the Council and shall decide all questions of order without
debate, subject, however, to an appeal by any Council member. Any ruling by the
Chairman may be overruled by a majority of the Council members present.
   3.   Recognition of Council Members. Every member of Council desiring to
speak shall address the chair and, upon recognition by the Chairman, shall
confine remarks to the question under debate, avoiding indecorous language or
reference to personalities. A member of Council, once recognized, shall not be
interrupted when speaking unless it is for the purpose of calling such person
to order. If a member of Council, while speaking, is called to order, said
person shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined. When two
or more Councilmen request the floor at the same time, the Chairman shall name
the one entitled to the floor.
   4.   Official Actions.
      a.   Official action. Except as provided in subsection (i), (ii), (iii)
or (iv), Council may not take official action on a matter of agency business at
a meeting if the matter was not included in the final agenda as distributed
pursuant to §
1-411(2).
         (i)   Emergency business. Council may take official action at a
regularly scheduled meeting or an emergency meeting on a matter of agency
business relating to a real or potential emergency involving a clear and
present danger to life or property regardless of whether public notice was
given for the meeting.
         (ii)   Business arising within 24 hours before meeting. An agency may
take official action on a matter of agency business that is not listed on a
meeting agenda if: (1) the matter arises or is brought to the attention of the
agency within the 24-hour period prior to the meeting; and (2) the matter is de
minimis in nature and does not involve the expenditure of funds or entering
into a contract or agreement by the agency.
         (iii)   Business arising during meeting. If, during the conduct of a
meeting, a resident or taxpayer brings a matter of agency business that is not
listed on the meeting agenda to the attention of the agency, the agency may
take official action to refer the matter to staff, if applicable, for the
purpose of researching the matter for inclusion on the agenda of a future
meeting, or, if the matter is de minimis in nature and does not involve the
expenditure of funds or entering into a contract or agreement, the agency may
take official action on the matter.
         (iv)   Amendment. A change to the final agenda approved pursuant to §
1-411(3).
This §
1-413(4) shall not apply to conferences, working sessions or executive sessions
as defined in the Pennsylvania Open Meetings Law.
      b.   Official actions of Council shall be taken by ordinance, resolution,
or motion as provided in the Charter and this Administrative Code. Council
action may be requested by a Council member by addressing the chair. Such
request shall be by motion. After the motion is seconded the Chairman shall,
unless he rules it out of order, immediately state the question. If the
question is debatable or amendable he shall then ask if Council is ready for
the question. When the debate, if any, has closed, the Chairman may request the
Township Clerk to restate the question. The Chairman shall then put the
question by requesting the roll.
   5.   Calling the Roll. The roll of Council members shall be called
alphabetically by the Township Clerk, except that the Chairman shall be called
last.
   6.   Time Limitations on Speaking. No member of Council shall speak more
than 10 minutes upon the same motion in the same meeting, nor for more than 5
minutes at a time, without the consent of the majority of the Council members
present. No Council member shall make a second speech on the same motion as
long as any Council member who has not spoken on that motion desires the floor.
   7.   Additional Rules of Procedure. Additional rules of procedure, insofar
as they are not inconsistent with the Charter and this Administrative Code, may
be adopted by Council by resolution.
(Ord. 70, § 3.10 (d), 2-14-79)
§ 1-414.   Journal.
A type-written record of proceedings, or minutes, shall be prepared for all
Council meetings, except executive and work sessions. Such records shall be
permanently maintained in chronological order in a locked binder-type journal.
The Township Clerk shall prepare the minutes and maintain the journal.
(Ord. 70, § 3.10(e), 2-14-79)
§ 1-415.   Content and Format of Minutes.
   1.   Preface. The minutes of each meeting shall be prefaced by the
following:
      A.   Name of the Assembly.
      B.   Type of Meeting.
      C.   Date of Meeting.
   2.   Order. The format of the minutes shall reflect the order of business of
the stated meeting. A description or summary of all proceedings shall be
entered in the minutes.
   3.   Contents.
      A.   The minutes shall contain the full text of each motion followed, as
applicable, by the names of the Councilmen who introduced and seconded the
motion, a summary of any pertinent discussion concerning the motion, the record
of the roll call vote, and the final statute of the motion.
      B.   If action is taken upon a matter of agency business added to the
final agenda under this § 1-411(3), the minutes of the meeting shall reflect
the substance of the matter added, the vote on the addition and the announced
reasons for the addition.
(Ord. 70, § 3.10(e), 2-14-79; as amended by Ord. 635, 10-6-21)
§ 1-416.   Approval of Minutes.
The minutes of any Council meeting shall be considered unofficial and shall not
be entered in the journal until signed by the Township Clerk and approved by
Council by motion. A copy of the unofficial minutes shall be provided to each
Council member a minimum of 5 days prior to voting for approval. Should Council
for any reason fail to approve the minutes of a meeting within 90 days
following receipt of such minutes, those minutes shall be deemed approved as
presented.
(Ord. 70, § 3.10(e), 2-14-7)
§ 1-417.   Journal Open to Public Inspection.
The journal shall remain in the Township Municipal Building and shall be
available for public inspection during normal business hours. Copies of any
part of the journal shall be made available to the public at a reasonable
price.
(Ord. 70, § 3.10(e), 2-14-79)
§ 1-418.   Voting by Council.
The requirements for voting by the Council are set forth in the Charter.
(Ord. 70, § 3.10, 2-14-79)
§ 1-419.   Citizen's Right to be Heard.
   1.   Courtesy of the Floor. The agenda for each regular meeting of Council
shall include provisions for Courtesy of the Floor, during which time the
citizens and taxpayers of the Township may address the Council and discuss any
matters concerning the Township, other than those appearing elsewhere on the
agenda. Unless extended by motion of those Council members present, Courtesy of
the Floor shall be limited to two time periods of 15 minutes each, at the
beginning and end of the meeting.
   2.   Request for Particular Matters. Any citizen or taxpayer of the Township
who desires to have a matter of business placed on the agenda of a regular
meeting shall make such request by providing written notice to the Township
Manager at least 7 days prior to the meeting. Inclusion of such items on the
agenda shall be at the discretion of the Township Manager in consultation with
the Council Chairman.
   3.   Opportunity to Address Council. Citizens and taxpayers of the Township
who are present at the meeting shall be provided the opportunity to address
Council on any agenda item. Such opportunity shall be provided prior to any
vote of Council on said agenda item.
   4.   Non-Residents. Persons other than residents and taxpayers of the
Township may be granted the privilege to address Council. Granting of such
privilege shall be at the discretion of the Chairman. However, any such ruling
by the Chairman may be overruled by a majority of the Council members present.
   5.   Procedure for Addressing Council. Any person wishing to speak shall
address the Chair, and upon recognition by the Chairman, shall rise and state
his/her full name and address and shall confine discussion to the agenda item
at hand, avoiding indecorous language or reference to personalities. Once
recognized, no person shall be interrupted while speaking unless it is for the
purpose of calling such person to order. When called to order, that person
shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined.
   6. Time Limitations. No person shall speak more than 10 minutes on the same
agenda item, nor more than 5 minutes at a time, without the consent of a
majority of the Council members present. No person shall make a second speech
on the same agenda item as long as another person who has not spoken desires
the floor. The Chairman, subject to being overruled by a majority of the
Council members present, may limit public participation to a maximum of 15
minutes on any agenda item.
   7. Limiting the Number of Speakers. When a group of persons wishes to
address the Council on the same subject, the Chairman may require that a
spokesman be chosen by the group to address Council and limit the number of
persons addressing Council on the same matter so as to avoid unnecessary
repetition.
   8.   Removal from Meeting. Any person making offensive, insulting,
threatening, insolent, slanderous or obscene remarks or who becomes boisterous
or who makes threats against any person or against public order and security
while in the Council meeting shall be forthwith barred by the Chairman from
further audience at that meeting unless permission to continue is granted by
majority vote of the Council members present.
(Ord. 70, § 3.11, 2-14-79)
PART 5
ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS
§ 1-501.   Ordinances in General.
The requirements as to form and procedure for adoption of ordinances are set
forth in the Charter.
(Ord. 70, § 3.13, 2-14-79)
§ 1-502.   Actions Requiring an Ordinance.
Actions of Council required to be done by ordinance shall include but not be
limited to those set forth in the Charter. Other actions may be taken by
ordinance at the discretion of Council.
(Ord. 70, § 3.12, 2-14-79)
§ 1-503.   Emergency Ordinance.
The requirements for enacting emergency ordinances are set forth in the
Charter. Emergency ordinances shall have the full force and effect of
ordinances in general.
(Ord. 70, § 3.14, 2-14-79)
§ 1-504.   Codes of Technical Regulations.
The requirements for this section shall be as provided by the Charter.
(Ord. 70, § 3.15, 2-14-79)
§ 1-505.   Authentication and Recording; Codification; Printing.
The requirements for this section shall be as provided in the Charter.
(Ord. 70, § 3.16, 2-14-79)
§ 1-506.   Enforcement of Ordinances.
The Township Manager shall be responsible for the enforcement of ordinances.
Upon approval by Council resolution, the Manager may delegate authority for the
enforcement of ordinances to any Township employee(s) and/or to a Code
Enforcement Officer hired for such purpose.
(Ord. 70, § 3.17, 2-14-79)
PART 6
ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICES AND DEPARTMENTS
A. Administration Generally.
§ 1-601.   Oath of Office.
Oaths of office shall be taken and signed before a Judge, Justice of the Peace
or Notary Public of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, prior to assumption of
office.
(Ord. 70, § 6.02, 2-14-79)
§ 1-602.   Responsibilities of Office, Agency, and Department heads. The heads
of departments, offices and agencies shall:
      A.   Responsible to Township Manager. Be immediately responsible to the
Township Manager for the effective and efficient administration of their
respective departments, offices and agencies, and all activities assigned
thereto.
      B.   New Practices. Keep informed as to the latest practices in their
particular field and shall inaugurate, with approval of the Township Manager,
such new practices as appear to be of benefit to the Township.
      C.   Submit Reports. Submit reports of the activities of his department
as required by the Township Manager.
      D.   Filing and Indexing of Records, Reports. Establish and maintain a
system of filing and indexing records and reports in sufficient detail to
furnish all information necessary for proper control of department, office or
agency activities and to form a basis for the reports to the Township Manager.
      E.   Appointment and Removal of Subordinates. Have power, when authorized
by the Township Manager, to appoint and remove subordinates subject to
Personnel System regulations.
      F.   Maintenance of Property and Equipment. Be responsible for the proper
maintenance of all Township property and equipment used in his department,
office or agency.
(Ord. 70, § 501 (a), 2-14-79)
§ 1-603.   Interdepartmental Cooperation.
Each department, office and agency shall furnish, upon authorization by the
Township Manager, to any other department, office or agency such service, labor
and materials as may be requisitioned by the head of such department, office,
or agency, and as its own facilities permit, through the same procedure and
subject to the same audit and control as other Township expenditures.
(Ord. 70, § 5.01(b), 2-14-79)
§ 1-604.   Personnel System.
The personnel system shall be as provided in the Charter and in Part 7.
(Ord. 70, § 5.02, 2-14-79)
§ 1-605.   Public Documents.
All public documents shall be subject to the provision of the Charter and this
Code.
(Ord. 70, § 5.07, 2-14-79)
B. Township Manager.
§ 1-621.   Appointment; Qualifications; Compensation.
The requirements for appointment, qualifications and compensation are set forth
in the Charter. Council may change the Manager's compensation by resolution at
any regular or special meeting of Council, unless such compensation and changes
thereto are fixed by contract.
(Ord. 70, § 4.01, 2-14-79)
§ 1-622.   Removal.
The procedures for removal of the Manager are set forth in the Charter. If the
Manager requests a public hearing as provided in the Charter, such hearing
shall be subject to the provisions for Council investigations in the Charter
and this Code.
(Ord. 70, § 4.02, 2-14-79)
§ 1-623.   Vacancy.
The requirements for this Section shall be as provided by the Charter.
(Ord. 70, § 4.03, 2-14-79)
§ 1-624. Acting Township Manager.
Approval of, appointment of or removal of an acting Township Manager by Council
shall be by resolution. Should the Manager, for any reason, fail to designate
an acting Township Manager, the Council shall do so by resolution.
(Ord. 70, § 4.04, 2-14-79)
§ 1-625.   Powers and Duties.
Unless otherwise designated or prohibited by law, the Manager shall have, but
not be limited to, the following additional powers and duties:
      A.   Filling Vacancies. He may designate an officer or employee to
perform the duties of any office or position in the administrative service
which is vacant or which lacks administration due to the absence or disability
of the incumbent.
      B.   Prescribe Rules and Regulations. He may prescribe such rules and
regulations as he deems necessary or expedient for the conduct and operation of
administrative departments and revoke, suspend or amend any rule or regulation
of the administrative service by whomever prescribed unless contained in an
ordinance or resolution adopted by Council.
      C.   Overrule Actions by Department Heads. He may overrule or set aside
any action taken by the head of any department, office or agency appointed by
the Manager.
      D.   Establish Committees. He may establish committees within the
administrative service and appoint officers and employees as shall be necessary
for the purposes of considering and resolving administrative problems.
(Ord. 70, § 4.05, 2-14-79)
§ 1-626. Emergency Powers.
The requirements for this Section shall be as provided in the Charter.
(Ord. 70, § 4.06, 2-14-79)
C. Other Officials.
§ 1-631.   Additional Duties of Township Attorney.
In addition to the duties as set forth in the Charter (See §
5.03) the Township Attorney shall:
   A.   Advise Township. Advise the Council, or its Committees or any Township
Officer when authorized by the Manager, upon all legal questions arising in the
conduct of Township business.
   B.   Prepare or Review Ordinances. Prepare or review ordinances when so
requested by the Council or any Committee thereof.
   C.   Attend Meetings. Attend meetings as designated by Council.
   D.   Prepare and Review Contracts, Bonds. When requested, prepare and review
contracts and instruments to which the Township is a party and shall approve as
to form, all bonds required to be submitted to the Township.
   E.   Report on Litigation. Immediately report the outcome of any litigation
in which the Township has an interest to the Township Manager and Council.
   F.   Maintain Complete Records. Maintain a complete record of all Township
legal matters.
   G.   Preparing Successor in Office. Deliver all records, documents and
property of every description in his possession, belonging to the Township, to
his successor in office, who shall give him duplicate receipts therefor, one of
which he shall file with the Township Manager.
(Ord. 70, § 5.03, 2-14-79)
§ 1-632. Additional Duties of Township Engineer.
In addition to the duties as set forth in the Charter (See §
5.04) the Township Engineer shall:
   A.   Advise Township. Advise the Council, or its Committees, or any Township
Officer when authorized by the Manager, upon all engineering questions arising
in the conduct of Township business.
   B.   Prepare or Review Ordinances. Prepare or review ordinances when so
requested by the Council or any Committee thereof.
   3.   Attend Meetings. Attend meetings as designated by Council.
   D.   Prepare and Review Contracts. When requested, prepare and review
contracts and instruments to which the Township is a party.
   E.   Report Outcome of Engineering Matters. Immediately report the outcome
of any engineering matters in which the Township has an interest to the
Township Manager and Council.
   F.   Maintain Complete Records. Maintain a complete record of all Township
Engineering matters.
   G.   Preparing Successor in Office. Deliver all records, documents and
property of every description in his possession, belonging to the Township, to
his successor in office, who shall give him duplicate receipts therefor, one of
which he shall file with the Township Manager.
(Ord. 70, § 5.04, 2-14-79)
§ 1-633.   Township Clerk.
The Township Clerk shall follow the specifications and duties that are assigned
to him by the Charter (see §
5.06) or the Township Manager and by this Administrative Code.
(Ord. 70. § 5.06, 2-14-79)
D. Township Treasury Department.
§ 1-641.   General.
The powers, duties and authority of the Township Treasury Department shall be
those enumerated in the Charter (see Sec.
5.05) and this Administrative Code.
(Ord. 70, § 5.05, 2-14-79)
§ 1-642.   Cooperative Investment.
   1.   The Township Manager is authorized to invest funds found to be in
excess of current Township needs through the Cooperative investment Pooling
Program of the County of Lehigh in certificates of deposit of properly insured
banking institutions.
   2.   The Township Manager is authorized to invest funds found to be in
excess of current Township needs through Certificates of Deposit of financial
institutions that are federally insured, notes and obligations of the United
States Government, and notes and obligations of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 73, § 2, 4-11-79)
§ 1-643. Pennsylvania Local Government Investment Trust.
   1.   The Pennsylvania Local Government Investment Trust was formed in
accordance with the authorization contained in the Intergovernmental
Cooperation Act (1972 P.L. 762 No. 180), initially by the Boroughs of
Chambersburg and Emmaus.
   2.   The Intergovernmental Cooperation Act provides that any joint
cooperation agreement shall be deemed in force as to any municipality, when the
same has been adopted by ordinance by all cooperating municipalities.
   3.   This Township shall join with other muncipalities in accordance with
the Pennsylvania Intergovernmental Cooperation Act by becoming a settlor of the
Pennsylvania Local Government Investment Trust (the Trust) and entering into
the Declaration of Trust, which is adopted by reference with the same effect as
if it had been set out verbatim in this section and a copy of which shall be
filed with the minutes of the meeting at which this section was adopted.
   4.   This Township is authorized to purchase shares in the Trust from time
to time with available municipal funds, and to redeem some or all of those
shares from time to time as funds are needed for municipal purposes. These
actions are to be taken by the officers designated for this purpose, pursuant
to resolution by the Township Council.
   5.   The Trustees of the Trust are designated as having official custody of
this Township's funds which are invested by the purchase of shares in the
Trust.
   6.   As required by the Intergovernmental Cooperation Act the following
matters are specifically found and determined:
      A.   The conditions of the agreement are set forth in the Declaration of
Trust referred to in this §
1-643(1).
      B.   This Township's participation in the Trust shall be terminable at
any time by ordinance.
      C.   The Declaration of Trust and the purchase of its shares are for the
purpose of investing this Township's funds in obligations which are otherwise
legal investments as part of a pooled arrangement with other governmental
units, thereby achieving economic and other advantages of pooled investments.
      D.   It is not necessary to finance the agreement authorized herein from
municipal funds except through the purchase of shares in the Trust.
      E.   The Trust shall be managed by a Board of Trustees as set forth in
the Declaration of Trust and the By-Laws provided for therein.
      F.   Shares may be purchased and redeemed from time to time as this
Township may determine to be necessary or appropriate.
(Ord. 105, 5-13-81)
PART 7
EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS
A.   General Regulations.
§ 1-701.   Official Bonds.
   1.   Designation of Additional Employees. In addition to those employees
specifically enumerated in the Charter (see §
6.01), the Council may require Fidelity and/or Surety Bonds for such other
Township Officials, officers or employees as it designates. Such designation
shall be made by ordinance or resolution and shall specifically state the
office or position to which it applies as well as the amount in dollars of the
bond.
   2.   Conditions on Bonds. Fidelity and Surety Bonds are conditioned upon the
faithful performance and discharge of respective duties and proper application
and payment of all money or property for which an official, officer or employee
is responsible by virtue of his office.
   3.   Designating Dollar Amounts. For the employees enumerated in the Charter
(see §
6.01), the council shall designate by ordinance or resolution the dollar amount
of the required bonds.
(Ord. 70, § 6.01, 2-14-79)
§ 1-702.   Conflicts of Interest.
All Township officials, officers and employees are subject to the provisions of
Act 1978- 170 as applicable. If the Township Council shall determine that no
conflict exists concerning a given subject based on the disclosure on file, an
official, officer or employee may freely participate in all activity concerning
such subject (see Charter, §
6.03 - Conflicts of Interest).
(Ord. 70, § 6.03, 2-14-79)
§ 1-703.   Soliciting of Employment Favors.
The provisions of this section are set forth in the Charter (see §
6.04). Individuals guilty of violating these provisions are subject to the
penalties provided in the Charter.
(Ord. 70, § 6.04, 2-14-79)
§ 1-704.   Private Use of Public Employees or Property.
Township employees and property shall be used exclusively for the benefit of
the Township. (see Charter, §
6.05 - Private Use of Public Employees or Property).
(Ord. 70, § 6.05, 2-14-79)
§ 1-705.   Political Activity.
Elected officials, officers and employees are prohibited from engaging in
partisan political activity during working hours and at all times in Township
offices and facilities. Penalties for violation of this section are provided in
the Charter. (see §
6.07 - Political Activity.)
(Ord. 70, § 6.07, 2-14-79)
§ 1-706.   Activities Prohibited.
Prohibited activities by Township personnel are enumerated in the Charter (see
§
6.08). Penalties for violation of these prohibitions are provided in the
Charter (see §
6.09).
(Ord. 70, § 6.08, 2-14-79)
§ 1-707.   Penalties.
   1.   Determining Violations of Charter. Determination of violation of the
Charter shall be made by the Council for elected and appointed officers and
officials and by the Manager for employees subject to his direction. (see
Charter §
6.06 - Penalty for Violation of Charter.)
   2.   Conforming to Crimes Code. All penalties provided shall be in
accordance with the Crimes Code of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. (see
Charter §
6.09 - Penalties.) [Ord. 551]
(Ord. 70, § 6.09, 2-14-79; as amended by Ord. 551, 12/18/2013)
B.   Conditions of Employment.
§ 1-721.   Hiring.
Hiring decisions are made in the Township by the Township Manager and the
Township employee’s immediate supervisor (if any) after they have determined
that the Township employee qualified for the job; that is, if the Township
employee has a good past employment record and has the necessary skills,
knowledge and ability to perform the job for which the Township employee is
being considered. Discrimination in hiring and promoting because of race,
color, creed, national origin, sex, age or physical disability is prohibited.
If there is any change in the Township employee’s address, marital status,
number of dependents or other personal data, the Township employee must inform
the Township Manager who will update your personal records accordingly.
(Ord. 83, § 3, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-722.   Hours of Work.
   1.   Non-Office Employees. Monday through Friday - 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.;
all with eight hours of work per day and ½ hour for lunch. Forty hours of work
per week. [Ord. 574]
   *This Section 722(1) does not apply to part-time employees.
   [Ord. 574]
2.   Office Employees. Monday through Friday - 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. 7 hours of
work per day with ½ hour for lunch. Thirty-five hours of work per week.
   *This Section 722(2) does not apply to part-time employees.
   [Ord. 611]
(Ord. 83, § 4, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 115, 3-10-82; by Ord. 424, 6/19/2002;
by Ord. 530, 2/1/2012, § 1; by Ord. 574, 6/3/2015; by Ord. 611, 4/3/2019; and
by Ord. 649, 12/20/2023)
§ 1-723.   Probationary Period.
During the first 6 months on the job the Township employee will be considered a
probationary employee. The Township employee’s work performance will
periodically be reviewed by his immediate supervisor (if any) and the Township
Manager. They will discuss, with the Township employee, work efficiency,
attitude toward the job, relationship with fellow workers, and ability to learn
and perform the responsibilities of the job.
(Ord. 83, § 5, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-724.   Salary; Pay Rates.
   1.   Generally. Township employees will be paid every other Friday, 26 times
a year. The rate of pay received will depend upon the type of work performed by
the Township employee. The more responsible or skilled jobs are paid at a
higher rate than the less responsible or less skilled jobs. Thus, the Township
employee’s rate of pay will depend upon his job classification. When the
Township employee receives his check, automatic deductions will have been made
for Federal Income Tax, Social Security, and other State and Local Taxes as
required by law. [Ord. 138]
   2.   Salary Increases. Salary increases for Township employees shall take
effect January 1 of each year and shall be established as follows:
      A.   Township Manager shall assess the overall performance of Township
operations during the current calendar year with respect to the state of fiscal
affairs, level of service, increases in efficiency and professional development
of the employees as a whole and recommend a "base increase" in the form of a
percentage for all employees.
      B.   Township Manager shall review individual employee performance and
determine eligibility for a "merit increase". This will involve input from
Department Heads overseeing employees' daily work, compliance and performance.
The Township Manager shall determine suggested merit increases based on
employee performance in the form of a percentage.
      C.   The Township Manager shall bring his/her recommended increases to
Council in December for both "base" and "merit" increases to Council for
review, discussion and approval.
      D.   The Township Manager's recommended increases shall not exceed 5%.
[Ord. 490; as amended by Ord. 597, 9/19/2018]
(Ord. 83, § 30, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 138, 6-30-83; by Ord. 212, 5-11-88;
by Ord. 377, 2/17/1999, § 1; by Ord. 393, 1110/2000, § 1; by Ord. 490, 10/20/
2008; and by Ord. 597, 9/19/2018)
§ 1-725.   Overtime Pay/Comp Time.
   1.   Overtime Pay. At times there may be unexpected or emergency situations
which may require the Township employee to work in excess of eight 8 hours in 1
day or 40 hours in 1 week. When this occurs, hourly and non-exempt salary
employees will be compensated for overtime pay at 1½ times your hourly rate.
Because the Township employee's job directly affects the operation of the local
government or the quality of service the public receives, he will be expected
to work overtime when asked. Refusal to work overtime could result in
disciplinary action.
   2.   Comp Time. Full time (non-office) employees shall have the option of
accumulating comp time for overtime hours in lieu of payment of wages for the
same. Comp time shall accrue
   at a rate of 1.5 times the number of overtime hours worked. Accumulated comp
time hours may be used for paid time off. Requests for compensatory time off
must be made to the Maintenance Supervisor in advance and will be approved
unless to do so would be unduly disruptive to Township operations. Comp time
hours not used by the end of a calendar year will be paid out to the employee
at their hourly rate. In the event of retirement or other termination of
employment, unused comp time hours will be paid out with the final paycheck.
(Ord. 83, § 7, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; by Ord. 604, 12/5/2018;
and by Ord. 650, 12/20/2023)
§ 1-726.   Vacation.
   1.   Amount of Vacation Time. The amount of paid vacation time will depend
on the length of service the Township employee has with the Township.
      A.   Except as provided in (B), the Township employee will not be
eligible for vacation until he has completed 1 year of continuous service with
the Township and his vacation must be taken in groups of at least 5 days or at
the discretion of the Township Manager. The following is the amount of vacation
accrued after so many years of service:
 
Years of Full Time Service      Weeks of Vacation
0 - Year                        0 - Days
1 Year, But Less Than 5 Years   10 - Work Days
5 Years, But Less Than 15 Years 15 - Work Days
15 or more                      20 - Work Days
 
      B.   The Township Manager shall be eligible for paid vacation after he
has completed three months of continuing service for the Township as follows:
 
Full Time Service                 Weeks of Vacation
0-3 Months                        0 Days
3 Months, but less than 15 months 15 Work Days per year
15 Months or more                 20 Work Days per year
 
   2.   Accumulation of Vacation Time. Any vacation the Township employee has
earned should be taken in the 1-year period between the anniversary date on
which he became entitled to the vacation and his succeeding anniversary date.
Commencing in the year 2002, Township employees will not be permitted to carry
over vacation time into the next year. Any unused vacation at the end of a
given calendar year will be paid to the employee at the time of the last
payroll of the year. [Ord. 413]
   3.   Scheduling. Approval for the scheduling of vacations rests with the
Township Manager, who will, in making his decision, take into account your
performance as well as the efficient management of the work force. If a
vacation is taken during a week which contains a paid holiday, one additional
day vacation will be given in all circumstances.
   4.   Unused Time. If the Township employee terminates his employment and has
unused vacation time, he will be compensated for it, but he must give at least
2 weeks notice of his intended termination. Formula for compensation of
vacation at termination: number of days entitled per year divided by 12 (months
per year), times the number of full months worked.
   5.   Emergency Recall. It is hoped it will never be necessary, but unusual
or emergency situations may require the Township Manager or Maintenance
Supervisor to recall the Township employee to work during his scheduled
vacation. If this happens, the Township employee will be compensated at
overtime pay at 1½ times your hourly rate. Arrangements as to the scheduling of
the remainder of your vacation will be made.
(Ord. 83, § 8, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; by Ord. 413, 12/19/
2001, § 1; and by Ord. 592, 4/4/2018)
§ 1-727.   Paid Holidays.
   1.   Dates. Full time employees will receive the following paid holidays:
 
New Years Eve    Friday After Thanksgiving Day
New Year’s Day Independence Day
Christmas Eve    Labor Day
Christmas Day    Memorial Day
Thanksgiving Day 4 Personal Days
President’s DayGood Friday
 
[Ord. 559]
   2.   Holiday Falling on Weekends. When the holiday falls on either a
Saturday or Sunday, the Township Manager shall designate the preceding Friday
or following Monday as the date of the holiday recognition based on community
observances.
   3.   Ineligibility. If the Township employee is absent from work the day
before or the day after the holiday for any unauthorized reason, he will not be
eligible for holiday pay.
   4.   Working on Holidays. If the Township employee is required to work on a
holiday, he will be compensated at overtime pay at double time his hourly rate.
Same shall be retroactive to December 1, 1990. [Ord. 258]
   5.   Additional Paid Holidays. Additional paid holidays may be granted by
Resolution of Council.
(Ord. 83, § 9, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 111, 1-13-82; by Ord. 147, 12-28-83;
by Ord. 171, 2-13-85; by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; by Ord. 258, 2-20-1991; by Ord.
413, 12/19/2001, § 2; by Ord. 559, 6/4/2014; by Ord. 652, 12/20/2023; and by
Ord. 653, 12/20/2023, § 2)
§ 1-728.   Sick Leave.
   1.   Amount; Accumulation. As a full time salaried employee, the Township
employee will earn 1 work day of sick leave for each month worked in a given
calendar year up to a total of 12 work days per year, and he may accumulate up
to 120 days of sick leave. The Township employee will be given credit for a
full month worked if he has worked at least 15 days in that month. Vacation
time and holidays shall count as days worked for the purpose of sick leave.
Accumulated sick time is not payable to the employee at termination of
employment (including retirement).
   2.   Requesting Sick Leave. When requesting sick leave, the Township
employee must, except in unusual or emergency situations, notify the Township
Manager before his normal work reporting time. The Township Manager may, if he
feels the Township employee is abusing sick leave, require the Township
employee to provide a certificate from his doctor stating his illness and his
inability to report to work. Sick leave in excess of 5 continuous work days
requires a doctor's certificate stating that the Township employee is fit to
return to work.
   3.   Abuse of Benefit. Patterns of sick leave usage that indicate abuse of
this benefit will be subject to review by the Township Manager.
(Ord. 83, § 10, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; and by Ord. 605, 12/5/
2018)
§ 1-729.   Funeral Leave.
When death occurs in the Township employee's family the Township allows
salaried employees a number of days off. The Township employee is entitled to 3
days off with pay (including weekends) in the event of the death of his Mother,
Father, Spouse, Child, Brother or Sister, and Immediate Family member, from the
date of death, with prior approval from the Township Manager. For the purposes
of this section, Immediate Family is described as Spouse, Parents, Brother or
Sister, Children, Grandchildren, Mother/Father in-Law or any relative that
resided with the employee. The Township employee is entitled to 1 day off with
pay (including weekends) in the event of the death of a Mother-in-Law, Father-
in-Law, Daughter-in-Law, Son-in-Law, Grandparent, Grandchild, Aunt, Uncle,
Sister-in-Law, Brother-in-Law, other family members. For the purposes of this
section, other family members are described as Grandparent- in-Law, Aunt,
Uncle, first cousin or an in-law from the date of death with prior approval of
the Township Manager. This leave shall not count as sick leave time.
(Ord. 83, § 11, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; by Ord. 413, 12/19/
2001, § 3; and by Ord. 652, 12/20/2023, § 3)
§ 1-730.   Leave of Absence Without Pay.
   1.   Circumstances. In certain circumstances the Township will approve leave
of absence without pay. These circumstances might include pregnancy, special
training, educational pursuits or a bona fide injury or illness when all
accumulated sick leave has been used by the employee and there may be other
valid reasons for allowing a leave of absence without pay. Request for this
leave must be made to the Township Manager.
   2.   Requests. A written request to the Township Manager for a leave of
absence without pay will be granted at the Township Manager's discretion. The
Township Manager may request advice from the Personnel Board with respect to
any requests for leave of absence. [Ord. 439]
   3.   Eligibility for Benefits. When the Township employee is on leave of
absence without pay, he may be eligible for life insurance and hospitalization
coverage up to a maximum of 90 days; however, the Township employee cannot earn
sick leave, vacation or holiday pay.
(Ord. 83, § 12, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; and by Ord. 439, 7-2-
2003)
§ 1-731.   Military Leave.
   1.   Providing Copy of Orders. If for any reason the Township employee is
called to active military service during his employment with the Township, he
will be granted military leave without pay. Before this leave can be granted,
however, the Township employee must provide the Township Manager with a copy of
his orders. Upon completion of his military obligation, the Township employee
may return to his job if, once again, the Township employee provides the
Manager a copy of his orders and provide this copy within ninety (90) days of
his discharge from the service.
   2.   Enlistment. The Township employee will have the same opportunities for
reemployment with the Township if he enlists in times of war, armed conflict,
or in an emergency, proclaimed by the President of the United States or the
Governor. In cases of enlistment, however, the Township employee must request
to be reemployed within 90 days after his first enlistment or when the
emergency or armed conflict was or is concluded.
   3.   Training Leave. If the Township employee is a member of the
Pennsylvania National Guard or other Military Reserve, he will be granted up to
15 days per year of compensated military leave to attend required training,
less any military pay received. This is in addition to his vacation leave. The
Township employee must give a copy of his orders to the Township Manager.
(Ord. 83, § 13, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-732.   Jury Duty.
The Township employee will receive no pay for the number of work days he is on
jury duty. After a receipt for his services is submitted to the Township
Manager, he will receive at the next regular pay period, a supplemental pay
which will reflect his regular pay lost minus his jury duty monies. Mileage
paid to the employee while attending jury duty will not reflect in this
deduction.
(Ord. 83, § 14, 4-9-80)
§ 1-733.   Employee Grievances.
   1.   Procedure. In the event of a disagreement between the Township and an
employee, the employee may file a grievance in writing. Within 72 hours after
receiving the employee's written grievance, the Township Manager will then
forward the written grievance to the Personnel Board, who will within 10 work
days after receipt from the Manager respond in writing to the employee's
grievance, agreeing or disagreeing with the employee's appeal and explaining
the reason why. A copy of the board's decision will also be sent to the
Township Manager. If the employee or Township Manager disagrees with the
Personnel Board's decision, or if the Board fails to respond, either may, by
the next regularly scheduled meeting, submit his grievance to the Hanover
Township Council who shall either agree or disagree with the Personnel Board's
decision. The Township employee and Manager will receive a reply in writing
from the Council 3 work days after such scheduled meeting.
   2.   If a CDL employee shall have a grievance regarding:
      A.   His dismisal or discipline by the Township Manager for violation of
the Township's Drug and Alcohol Policy and Testing Program, Stat. Code, Chap.
1, § 770 et seq., or a positive test result thereunder; or,
      B.   The Township's administration of the aforesaid Drug and Alcohol
Policy and Testing Program;
   the employee must submit his grievance directly to the Hanover Township
Council at its next regularly scheduled meeting, instead of submitting his
grievance to the Personnel Board. The Council shall respond and send notice of
its response as provided in Subsection (1) to this Section. For purposes of
this subsection, the phrase "next regularly scheduled meeting" shall mean the
first Council meeting occurring more than 72 hours after the administrative act
or omission which allegedly causes employee's grievance.
   3.   Employee's Status During Grievance Procedure. If the employee's
grievance concerns a reprimand, suspension, demotion or dismissal by his
supervisor, such reprimand, suspension, demotion or dismisaal shall remain in
effect during the grievance procedure. Invocation of the grievance procedure in
no way acts as a supersedeas of the supervisor's action.
(Ord. 83, § 15, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; and by Ord. 324, 12-
20-95, § 4)
§ 1-734.   Disciplinary Actions.
   1.   By Township Manager. The Township Manager may reprimand, suspend,
demote or dismiss, if necessary, for just cause. Violation of work rules set
forth in § 735 will be grounds for immediate dismisaal. [Ord. 324]
   2.   Minor Offenses. Except for violation of the work rules which are
grounds for dismissal, employees will receive warning notices from the Township
Manager as follows:
      A.   One oral warning for the first minor offense followed by:
      B.   One written warning for the second minor offense followed by:
      C.   One day off without pay for the third minor offense followed by:
      D.   Three days off without pay for the fourth minor offense. (Ord. 83, §
16, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 3)
§ 1-735. Employees Work Rules.
   1.   At times it is necessary to discipline a Township employee in order to
maintain an orderly and efficient Township operation, one which will be healthy
and safe for all employees and will ensure the Township's good reputation and
protect its property. Failure to obey these rules will subject the violating
Township employee to disciplinary action up to and including discharge. The
Township intends to enforce them fairly. When discipline is to be taken against
an employee, the Township will consider the seriousness of the action, the
employee's past conduct record, and the circumstances under which the violation
occurred. If the Township employee has a question concerning these work rules,
he may discuss them with the Township Manager.
      A.   The Township employee must be at his appointed work place, ready to
work at his regular starting time and must remain there, except during lunch
periods, until the regular quitting time.
      B.   The Township employee shall not conduct any personal business during
working hours.
      C.   The following are grounds for immediate dismissal:
         (1)   Bringing weapons, intoxicating liquors or illegal drugs onto the
Township premises.
         (2)   Fighting
         (3)   Smoking in unauthorized areas.
         (4)   Discarding matches or cigarettes carelessly.
         (5)   Littering work areas.
         (6)   Falsification of records and reports.
         (7)   Making or stating false claims of injury.
         (8)   Violation of safety rules or taking part in any activity which
may result or create a safety hazard to himself or others.
         (9)   Removing Township property, records or other materials without
the permission of the Township Manager.
         (10)   Misusing or damaging Township property.
         (11)   Horseplay
         (12)   Gambling
         (13)   Unexcused lateness or excessive absence.
         (14)   Immoral conduct or indecency.
         (15)   Refusal to follow orders of the Township employee's supervisor.
         (16)   Sleeping on the job.
         (17)   Reporting to work in an unfit physical condition or in an
intoxicated state.
         (18)   Using profane or abusive language.
         (19)   Failure to wear safety equipment or to use safety devices.
         (20)   Failure to be responsible for all Township tools, equipment, or
property assigned or requisitioned to you or in your care.
         (21)   Conduct damaging to the Township's reputation or ability to
provide public service.
         (22)   Failure to report any injury or accident immediately.
         (23)   Failure to notify in writing to the Township Manager of any
change in the Township employee's personal data.
         (24)   Soliciting, petitioning or distribution of any kind, without
written permission of the Township Manager.
         (25)   Accepting a gift when given under circumstances indicating the
hope or expectation of receiving a favor or better treatment than is generally
provided to the public.
         (26)   Actively participating in political activities during the
Township employee's working hours.
         (27)   Discourteous behavior to the public.
         (28)   Posting of notices without authorization from the Township
employee's supervisor.
         (29)   Disclosing confidential information.
         (30)   Misuse of the Township employee's authority.
         (31)   Failure of the Township employee to perform or neglecting his
job, duties and responsibilities.
         (32)   Failure of the Township employee to report to his supervisor an
unexpected illness or absence and to provide the reason(s) for it.
         (33)   Testing positive under the Township's Drug and Alcohol Testing
Program as set forth in subpart D of this Part. [Ord. 324]
         (34)   Violation of the Township's Drug and Alcohol Policy as set
forth in subpart D of this Part. [Ord. 324]
   2.   These rules and regulations are not meant to be inclusive and when
necessary additional rules and regulations may be added by Resolution of
Council.
(Ord. 83, § 29, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; and by Ord. 324, 12-
20-95, § 2)
§ 1-736.   Demotions.
Demotions may result from the Township employee's inability to perform his
assigned work, from disciplinary action, etc. The Township employee will be
given priority to be reappointed to his previous job if that job becomes
available within 1 year after his demotion period. The level of his priority
will depend on his work performance in relation to the work performance of
other co-workers.
(Ord. 83, § 17, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-737.   Promotions.
New job opportunities may arise and the Township Manager will inform the
Township employee of them. If the Township employee is interested in this
opportunity, his application must be in writing and include his name and the
vacancy for which he is applying. The Township Manager will decide who is to be
promoted after comparing the skills and abilities (taking into consideration
seniority) necessary to perform the job. If promoted, the Township employee
will be required to successfully complete a probationary period of 6 months. If
for some reason the Township employee does not successfully complete the
probationary period, he will be terminated unless a lower level job is
available.
(Ord. 83, § 18, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-738.   Provisional Appointments.
Occasionally other departments may be in need of extra help. When this happens,
the Township employee may be temporarily assigned elsewhere. The Township
employee's pay will not change as a result of a temporary assignment.
(Ord. 83, § 19, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-739.   Temporary Change in Status.
Sometimes ongoing operations require that the Township Manager temporarily
promote a lower level employee to a position in a higher pay range. Examples of
occurrence of this type might be an approved leave of absence or a long term
disability of the higher level employee. However, such promotion shall be at
the discretion of the Township Manager. If the employee is promoted for a
period exceeding 5 working days, he will at the next following pay period be
paid at the higher rate. The first 5 working days, however, will be reflected
at the employee's present rate.
(Ord. 83, § 20, 4-9-80)
§ 1-740.   Lay Offs.
Lay-offs of permanent Township employees occur only on rare occasions, mainly
as a result of budget cutbacks. When this happens, lay-offs decisions will take
into consideration operational needs, seniority and an employee's work
performance. If a Township employee is laid off, he will have priority for
appointments to any Township jobs which become available for which he is
qualified. This priority is limited to 18 months. If the Township employee is
laid off for more than 18 months, he will be paid for any vacation leave due
which he has not used, but will not be compensated for unused sick leave. If
rehired within the 18 month period, the Township employee will resume his
vacation seniority and sick leave which he had when he was laid off. However,
the Township employee's anniversary date will become his date of rehire and he
must complete one year of continuous service before earning vacations.
(Ord. 83, § 21, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-741.   Resignations and Retirements.
   1.   Resignation in Good Standing. To resign in good standing, the Township
employee must submit his resignation to the Township Manager at least 10
working days before leaving. Resignation in good standing is important because
it may affect your eligibility for reinstatement.
   2.   Reinstatement After Resignation. Providing a vacancy exists, the
Township employee may be reinstated to his job or a similar (or lower) job
within one year after resigning without going through the regular selection,
testing and probationary period.
   3.   The Township employee's previous termination or resignation must have
been made under honorable circumstances, and the Township employee must have
successfully completed the initial probationary period. By resigning, the
Township employee relinquishes all vacation, seniority and sick leave, but will
be compensated for all unused vacation time. The Township employee will begin
to earn vacation and sick leave upon reinstatement as if he was a new employee.
(Ord. 83, § 22, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-742.   Political Activity.
Each compensated Township employee may participate or refrain from
participating in political activity but no compensated Township employee shall
engage in political activity while performing the duties of his position with
the Township or service as a Township Committee person of a political party. No
employee in any way shall solicit any assessment, subscription, or contribution
for any political party, organization, committee, or candidate from any
compensated officer or Township Employee.
(Ord. 83, § 23, 4-9-80)
§ 1-743.   Outside Jobs.
The Township employee is allowed to have a part-time or full-time outside job,
but must first have, in writing, the approval of the Township Manager who will
decide if his outside employment will not conflict in any way with his Township
job. A note of caution needs to be stated. If the Township employee is injured
while on his other job, the Township is not liable to pay for any disability
incurred.
(Ord. 83, § 24, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-744.   Hospital and Medical Insurance.
The Township presently has for its full time employees Blue Cross/Blue Shield
and Major Medical Insurance.
(Ord. 83, § 25, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; by Ord. 413, 12/19/
2001, § 4; by Ord. 428, 12/4/2002; and by Ord. 455, 12/15/2004)
§ 1-745.   Insurance.
   1.   Life Insurance. The Township shall provide to the Township employee a
$35,000 term life insurance policy at the beginning of his employment. At that
time, the Township employee should inform the Manager of whom the beneficiary
(s) will be.
   2.   Disability Insurance. The Township will provide each employee with
short term and long term disability insurance. Short term shall be limited to
90 days: long term shall commence upon lapse of short term.
(Ord. 83, § 26, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; by Ord. 297, 10-20-93;
and by Ord. 598, 9-19-18)
§ 1-746.   Workmen's Compensation Benefits.
Pennsylvania Workmen's Compensation Act states that if a Township employee is
injured while performing Township duties, the Township employee is eligible to
receive two-thirds of his base salary (subject to allowable maximum and minimum
benefit levels at the time of the injury and other conditions of the Act) for a
period of time depending upon the seriousness of the injury. All reasonable
medical expenses are also paid. If the Township employee is injured on the job
or is disabled in any way as a result of his job, he must immediately report
this to the Township Manager. Failure to report an injury or a disability
within the time limits could result in the Township employee becoming
ineligible for Compensation Benefits.
(Ord. 83, § 27, 4-9-80; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-747.   Inservice Training.
The basis for Township approval and reimbursement of necessary expenses for
inservice training shall be the merits derived by the Township as a result of
such inservice education. All training and educational programs must be
approved by the Manager to qualify for reimbursement.
(Ord. 83, § 28, 4-9-80)
§ 1-748.   Dental and Vision Insurance.
   1.   The Township shall provide individual employee dental insurance to the
Township employee at the beginning of his employment. More information about
employee coverage will be given to the Township employee by his employer.
Township employees will be permitted to extend dental insurance coverage to
cover their family at a 50% insurance premium out-of-pocket cost to the
employee.
   2.   Hanover Township shall provide family vision care insurance to the
Township employee family. For the purpose of this section, family is described
as employee, spouse, or child(ren) under the age of 26.
(Ord. 111, 1-13-82; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88; by Ord. 413, 12/29/2001, §
5; by Ord. 429, 12/4/2002; and by Ord. 651, 12/20/2023)
§ 1-749.   Social Security Benefits.
Social Security Benefits shall be provided to the Township employee by the
Township at the beginning of his employment. More information about employee
coverage will be given to the Township employee by his employer.
(Ord. 111, 1-13-82; as amended by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-750.   Nate Frey Bereavement Benefit.
The Township recognizes that upon the death of an employee, termination of pay
may have a sudden adverse effect on employee's immediate family until insurance
or other resources can be accessed. Accordingly, Council shall award an amount
equal to two week's base salary for a salaried employee or two week's normal
compensation for an hourly employee, for the benefit of employee’s immediate
family (spouse and dependent children, stepchildren or parents living in the
decedent employee's household). Council may make such award to be used for the
benefit of the entire immediate family to any member of the immediate family,
guardian of a member of the immediate family, or other person or persons deemed
appropriate in the circumstances in the sole and absolute discretion of
Council. Neither Council nor the Township shall have any responsibility for or
oversight of the disbursement of such funds to the immediate family by the
recipient of the award.
(Ord. 623, 4-15-20)
§ 1-751.   On-Call Periods.
   1.   In order to assure the ability of the Township to respond to
unanticipated incidents outside of regular working hours, Maintenance
Department employees are required to be on-call during weekends (including
“long weekends” where a weekend is immediately preceded or followed by a
holiday) and remain within a distance to be able to respond if called by the
Township. Maintenance Department employees hired after December 19, 2018 are
required to be on call one full week at a time, in normal rotation with other
Maintenance Department employees on a schedule determined by the Township
Manager.
[Ord. 457]
   2.   Other employees who are not on-call may be called if incidents arise
and additional assistance is needed.
(Ord. 377, 2/17/1999, § 2; as amended by Ord. 457, 3/2/2005; and by Ord. 606,
12/5/2018)
