D. Drug and Alcohol Policy and Testing Program.
§ 1-770.   Purpose.
The Township adopts the following herein Drug and Alcohol Policy and Testing
Program for the following purposes:
      A.   To comply with the requirements of employers pursuant to the Federal
legislation regarding commercial driver's license (CDL) and the Federal
regulations thereto as far as they apply to this Township.
      B.   To conform the employment policies of this Township with the
requirements of said law and regulations.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-771.   Application.
This policy shall apply only to Township employees and applicants for
employment who are required to have a CDL license for employment by the
Township and who are assigned to operate vehicles or equipment requiring CDL
licensure.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-772.   Alcohol and Drug Policy.
   1.   Employees shall not use, sell, possess or receive alcohol or illegal
drugs, or distribute or sell prescription drugs while on duty. Violation of
these rules will subject the employee to discipline and/or dismissal at the
Township Manager's discretion, subject to any applicable provisions and
procedures of the collective bargaining agreement in effect, if any.
   2.   Prescription drugs must be kept in their original container identifying
the drug, dosage, date of prescription and physician. Employees are required to
notify their Supervisor if they are taking a prescription drug that could
impair their working ability or alertness and shall file with the Township a
statement on a form provided by the Township from the doctor who issued such
prescription stating whether or not such prescription drug will impair the
employee's ability to operate a CDL vehicle or equipment. The term "illegal
drugs" shall include drugs for which the employee does not have a valid
prescription.
(Ord. 325, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-773.   Testing Policy.
All Township employees and applicants who are subject to the drug and alcohol
policy must also participate in the drug and alcohol testing program. The
testing program will cover the following substances present in the body:
alcohol; cocaine; phencyclidine (PCP); marijuana; opiates (including herion);
amphetamines; and such other illegal drugs as may be identified from time to
time.
(Ord. 325, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-774.   Testing Procedures and Requirements.
All affected Township employees and applicants shall be tested according to the
following procedures:
      A.   Preemployment. All applicants for employment shall be tested for
drugs prior to acceptance for employment by the Township. Any applicant tested
positive shall not be considered for employment. Any refusal or failure by the
applicant to submit to these such tests shall be deemed a positive result.
      B.   Random. All Township employees subject to the drug and alcohol
policy will be tested for the above drugs on a random basis and without any
advance notice. Testing shall be done not less than on a quarterly basis. The
number of employees annually selected shall be at least 50% of the employees
for drug testing and 25% of the employees for alcohol testing.
      C.   Reasonable Cause. Any employee giving reasonable cause to believe
that he or she is in violation of the policy established in § 772 shall be
subject to testing immediately upon observation of such reasonable cause by
supervisory personnel. The reasonable cause shall be limited to behavior or
conduct observed at the work place or en route to a work place during working
hours. Observation shall be by supervisor personnel who have received at least
1 hour of training in drug use detection and 1 hour of training in alcohol use
detection. Supervisory personnel making reasonable cause observations shall
make and file with the Township a written report of the attendant
circumstances. Such reports shall be confidential.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-775.   Post-Accident.
Any employee involved in an accident as defined herein shall be tested for
drugs as soon after an accident occurs as is possible, but not later than 32
hours, and for alcohol as soon after an accident as possible, but not later
than 8 hours provided:
      A.   Testing should not take precedence over needed medical treatment or
other needed emergency measures.
      B.   If for any reason the test cannot be obtained within the times
provided, the test shall not be administered. However, refusal to submit to a
test or interfering with the successful completion of such a test shall be
deemed a positive result in accordance with § 775.1.
      C.   No employee shall consume alcohol or illegal drugs between the time
of the accident and the test administration.
      D.   An accident shall include any occurrence involving a CDL vehicle
where there is a fatality regardless of fault.
      E.   An accident shall include any occurrence involving a CDL vehicle
where the following conditions occur:
         (1)   Bodily injury requiring transportation of the injured person
away from the accident scene for treatment, or vehicle damages requiring the
vehicle to be towed.
         (2)   Issuance of a citation to the Township employee for a moving
violation.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-775.1. Test Standards.
Any refusal or failure by the CDL employee or applicant to submit to any test
required by this policy or the applicable law shall be deemed to be a positive
result. Refusal to submit to a test under this Policy shall include any act or
omission which prevents, thwarts or frustrates the objectives of this policy
including, without limitation, the following: refusal to submit in a timely
fashion to testing; refusal or failure by the employee or applicant to
complete, sign or initial the required testing form; refusal or failure without
good cause to provide any sample or provide an adequate sample for testing;
and/or, failure or refusal to otherwise cooperate with the testing process in a
way which prevents the completion of any required test.
      A.   Alcohol Testing. Alcohol testing shall be conducted using a
Federally approved breathalyzer. Any employee receiving a test result of
greater than two-hundredths (.02) but less than four-hundredths (.04) breath
alcohol level shall be removed from safety sensitive duties as defined in the
act and regulations, for 24 hours. Any test result of greater than four
hundredths (.04) breath alcohol level shall be considered a positive test.
      B.   Drug Testing. Drug testing shall be conducted by urine sample which
shall be analyzed at a Federally approved testing facility. Any test result
showing the presence of illegal drugs shall be considered a positive test.
      C.   If an employee shall test positive for either alcohol or illegal
drugs under this Section, the employee shall be subject to discipline and/or
dismissal, at the discretion of the Township Manager, or in accordance with
such other further policy as the Township may adopt in the future.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-776. Reemployment; Return to Duty.
   1.   If reemployment is offered to an employee who was previously dismissed
for a positive test result under §
1-775.1, the employee shall, prior to returning to duty:
      A.   Consult such drug and alcohol abuse professional to whom the
employee has been referred at the employee's expense.
      B.   Undergo all recommended treatment at the employee's expense.
      C.   Undergo drug and alcohol tests at the employee's expense and obtain
negative results.
   2.   Any employee returning to duty after a positive drug and/or alcohol
test shall be subject to unannounced follow-up tests for a period of 60 months
following a return to duty. At least six unannounced follow-up tests shall be
conducted in the 12 months following a return to duty.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-777.   Employee Assistance Program.
   1.   The Township Manager shall create the following lists and post them at
a place readily accessible to CDL employees:
      A.   A list of consultative and treatment services available in the area
for drug and alcohol abuse programs.
      B.   A list of education and training resources available in the area for
drug and alcohol abuse problems.
   2.   The Township Manager shall designate a place or service for referring
employees who test positive for drug and alcohol for consultation and
treatment.
   3.   The Township Manager shall establish and administer the following
program:
      A.   A hour training and educational program for employees.
      B.   One hour training programs in both drug and alcohol detection and
related matters for supervisory personnel. Said training program shall include
the following components:
         (1)   Effect of drug and alcohol abuse on health and safety.
         (2)   Manifestations of abuse and abuse detection.
         (3)   Documentation of training and implementation of this policy.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-778.   Test Results.
Employees will be notified of their positive test results. Test results shall
be retained by the Medical Review Officer responsible for testing. Said results
shall be held in strictest confidence and shall be accessible only to the
employee, the employer and such other persons authorized by law and shall not
be released to any other person except with the written consent of the
employee. The results of the test made known to the Township may be released to
future employers in accordance with the Federal regulations.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-779.   Confidentiality of Records.
All files, documents and records of the Township related to the application of
this policy to the individual employees shall be deemed and kept confidential
by the Township.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-780.   Record Keeping.
   1.   All of the records relating to the administration and results of the
Township alcohol and drug testing program for its CDL drivers will be
maintained for a minimum period of 5 years, except that individual negative
test results will be maintained for a minimum of 12 months.
   2.   The tests will be conducted by a licensed facility and will [be]
analyzed by a Medical Review Officer. The Medical Review Officer who is
appointed shall be a licensed doctor of medicine or osteopathy with knowledge
of drug and alcohol abuse disorders and who is employed by the Township or
group which the Township has joined to conduct alcohol and drug testing in
accordance with the Federal regulations. The Medical Review Officer shall be
the sole custodian of individual test results. The Medical Review Officer shall
retain the reports of individual results for a minimum of 5 years.
   3.   The Township shall retain in the employee's personnel file information
indicating only the following:
      A.   The employee submitted to a drug and/or alcohol test.
      B.   The date of such test.
      C.   The location of such test.
      D.   The identity of the person or entity performing the test.
      E.   Whether the test finding was "positive" or "subnegative."
   4.   The Township will also maintain an annual (calendar) year summary of
the records relating to the administration and results of the testing program
for its drivers under the Federal regulations.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-781.   Miscellaneous.
   1.   This policy shall be implemented with the constitutional and legal
rights of the employees subject to it.
   2.   This policy shall not be deemed to be a covenant of employment or any
other form of covenant or contract between the Township, and any employee.
   3.   Any collective bargaining agreement entered by the Township subsequent
to the adoption of this policy shall conform with the provisions of this
policy.
   4.   Any agreement for the sharing, leasing, lending or other transfer of
CDL employees between the Township and any other municipality or private
enterprise shall address in writing the status of said employees as to whether
they are employees of the receiving entity during the period of the transfer.
   5.   Any contract for services involving CDL employees shall expressly state
whether the contracting party is an independent contractor or employee/agent of
the Township.
   6.   The definition of terms shall be as contained in the relevant Federal
regulations.
   7.   A copy of this policy shall be delivered to every employee and
applicant for employment who is subject to it and to all supervisory personnel.
Such employee shall sign an acknowledgement of receipt of this policy.
   8.   A copy of the controlling law and Federal regulations shall be
maintained in the Township offices and shall be accessible to employees upon
request.
   9.   This policy shall be limited by any applicable Federal or State law or
municipal ordinance and by applicable collective bargaining agreements. Any
portion of this policy which directly conflicts with such a law, ordinance or
agreement will not be implemented in that jurisdiction or bargaining unit, but
shall be severable and shall not effect the validity and enforcement of the
remainder of the policy.
   10.   Employees agree to waive any liability against the Township arising
out of the Township's administration of this policy and its admin- istration of
the program established pursuant to Federal law or regulations regarding the
Township's responsibility for CDL drivers.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-782.   Implementation of Policy.
   1.   The Township Council is empowered to pass resolutions for the
implementation of this Drug and Alcohol Policy and Testing Program, including
the appointment of a Medical Review Officer and the testing facility. Such
resolutions shall effectuate Federal regulations establishing requirements
concerning drug and alcohol testing of CDL employees. In addition, the Township
Council may pass regulations which exceed the requirements of Federal
regulations, if Council deems such resolutions necessary for the safe operation
of its commercial vehicle.
   2.   Consortiums. The Township Council may by resolution enter its CDL
employees into a consortium for the purposes of drug and alcohol testing, as
permitted under the Federal regulations. In addition, the Township Manager may
enter into agreements concerning the consortium to provide for the testing of
CDL employees and for the training, assistance and education provisions of this
Part.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
§ 1-783.   Effective Date.
The Drug and Alcohol Policy and Testing Program shall be effective January 1,
1996, and shall continue in effect until amended or terminated by regulation of
the Township Council.
(Ord. 324, 12-20-95, § 1)
E.   Pennsylvania Municipal Retirement System Pension Plan.
§ 1-791.   Definitions.
   CONTRACT—the amended municipal pension plan contract between the
Pennsylvania Municipal Retirement Board and the Township effective January 1,
2012.
   RECOVERY ACT—the Municipal Pension Plan Funding Standard and Recovery Act,
53 P.S. § 895.101 et seq.
   RETIREMENT LAW—the Pennsylvania Municipal Retirement Law, 53 P.S. § 881.101
et seq.
   SYSTEM—the Pennsylvania Municipal Retirement System.
   TOWNSHIP—Hanover Township, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 528, 12/21/2011, § 1)
§ 1-792.   Enrollment in the Retirement System.
Hanover Township, being a member municipality of the system, hereby elects to
amend its municipal pension plan administered by the system in accordance with
Article IV of the Retirement Law, and does hereby agree to be bound by all the
requirements and provisions of the retirement law and the Recovery Act and to
assume all obligations, financial and otherwise, placed upon member
municipalities.
(Ord. 528, 12/21/2011, § 1)
§ 1-793.   Administration.
The Township hereby agrees that the system shall administer and provide the
benefits set forth in the contract entered into between the Pennsylvania
Municipal Retirement Board and the Township effective January 1, 2012.
(Ord. 528, 12/21/2011, § 1)
§ 1-794.   Contract Approval.
The passage and adoption of this Part by the Township is an official approval
and acceptance of the contract and the financial obligations resulting from the
administra tion of the contract.
(Ord. 528, 12/21/2011, § 1)
§ 1-795.   Payment.
Payment for any obligation established by the adoption of this Part and the
contract shall be made by the Township in accordance with the Retirement Law
and the Recovery Act. The Township hereby assumes all liability for any
unfundedness created due to the benefit structure set forth in the contract.
(Ord. 528, 12/21/2011, § 1)
§ 1-796.   Membership.
Membership in the system for Township employees shall be determined as set
forth in the contract.
(Ord. 528, 12/21/2011, § 1)
F.   Equal Opportunity Employment Policy.
§ 1-797.1.   Purpose.
The Township adopts the following herein Equal Opportunity Employment Policy
for the following purposes:
      A.   To comply with the requirements of employers pursuant to Title VII
of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, and the employment provisions of
the Pennsylvania Human Relations Act, as amended. The purpose of this Equal
Employment Opportunity Policy is to prevent and eliminate unlawful,
discriminatory practices in employment, because of race, color, religion,
ancestry, age, sex, national origin, non-job related disability, known
association with a disabled individual, possession of a diploma based on
passing a general education development test or willingness or refusal to
participate in abortion or sterilization.
      B.   To conform the employment policies of this Township with the require
ments of said laws and regulations.
(Ord. 399, 10/4/2000, § 797.1)
§ 1-797.2.   Application.
This policy shall apply to all Township employees and applicants for
employment.
(Ord. 399, 10/4/2000, § 797.2)
§ 1-797.3.   Equal Employment Opportunity Policy.
Hanover Township is an equal opportunity employer. This means that Hanover
Township does not discriminate against employees or job applicants on the basis
of race, color, religion, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, non-job related
disability, known association with a disabled individual, possession of a
diploma based on passing a general education development test or willingness or
refusal to participate in abortion or sterilization or on any other basis
prohibited by law. This nondiscrimination policy applies to all terms and
conditions of employment which include, but are not limited to, compensation,
hours, recruitment, selection, training, assignment, evaluation, promotion,
discipline and termination. Harassment based on any status or condition
protected by applicable laws as a form of discrimination prohibited by this
policy. Any employee who becomes aware of any incidence of harassment or
discrimination must bring the matter to the attention of their supervisor or
the Township Manager or as outlined below so that prompt and effective
corrective action may be taken.
(Ord. 399, 10/4/2000, § 797.3)
§ 1-797.4. Sexual Harassment Policy.
   1.   Sexual harassment in the workplace is a form of employment
discrimination. It is the policy of Hanover Township that sexual harassment of
employees or applicants for employment is strictly prohibited and will not be
tolerated. Under this policy, all employees share the responsibility for
assuring that the workplace is free from all forms of sexual harassment.
   2.   Sexual Harassment includes unwelcome sexual advances, request for
sexual favors and/or other verbal or visual or physical conduct of a sexual
nature where:
      A.   Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a
term or condition of an individual's employment.
      B.   Submission to or rejection of such conduct of an individual is used
as a basis of employment decisions effecting such individuals.
      C.   Such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering
with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or
offensive working environment.
   3.   Such conduct may also include action by members of the employee's own
sex. Thus, no manager, supervisor or other employee shall threaten or suggest,
either explicitly or implicitly, that another employee or applicant's refusal
to submit to sexual harassment in any form will adversely affect that person's
employment, performance evaluation ratings, wages, compensation, advancement,
assigned duties or any other term or condition of employment. In addition,
offering, promising or granting favored treatment to any other employee or
applicant for employment as a result of that person's engaging in or agreeing
to engage in sexual conduct as well as seeking in any way to make the
performance of a person's job more difficult because of that person's sex or
the refusal of that person to submit to sexual advances is strictly prohibited.
   4.   The following behavior is also prohibited: physical assaults of a
sexual nature, other unwanted and unnecessary contact with another employee,
unwelcomed propositions or sexual flirtation, direct or subtle pressure or
requests for dates of sexual activity, verbal abuse of a sexual nature
including, but not limited to, inappropriate verbal comments about an
individual's body or sexual activities, the inappropriate use of sexually
explicit or offensive language in discussions with or to describe an
individual, sexually explicit offensive jokes and the display in the workplace
of sexually suggestive objects or pictures.
(Ord. 399, 10/4/2000, § 797.4)
§ 1-797.5. Reporting Procedures.
   1.   Any individual that feels that he/she has been a victim of harassment
in any form, including sexual harassment, by any manager, supervisor, co-
worker, customer, client or any other person in connection with his/her
employment should bring the problem immediately to the attention of the
Township Manager.
If the complaint involves the Township Manager, or if the employee is
uncomfortable for any reason with discussion of such matters with the Township
Manager, the employee may bypass the Township Manager and instead should report
the matter promptly to the Chairperson of the Hanover Township Council.
   2.   Hanover Township will investigate all allegations of harassment in as
prompt and confidential a manner as possible and will take appropriate action
when warranted. Any employee that is found, as a result of such investigation,
to have engaged in harassment or discrimination in violation of this policy
will be subject to appropriate disciplinary action, up to and including
termination of employment. Furthermore, retaliation in any form against an
employee or applicant who exercises his/her right to make a complaint under
this policy or who cooperates in the investigation of any such complaint is
strictly prohibited and will itself be cause for appropriate disciplinary
action.
   3.   Any question regarding this policy should be addressed to the Township
Manager. (Ord. 399, 10/4/2000, § 797.5)
PART 8
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
A. Recreation Commission.
§ 1-801.   Title.
The name of this organization shall be the Hanover Township (Lehigh County)
Recreation Commission.
(Ord. 84, Art. 1, 4-9-80)
§ 1-802.   Authorization to Restablish By-Laws.
The authorization for the establishment of these By-Laws is pursuant to the
authority of the Township Council under the Hanover Township Home Rule Charter.
(Ord. 84, Art 2, 4-9-80)
§ 1-803.   Membership.
   1.   Number and Terms. Members shall consist of seven persons to be
appointed by the Township Council. Members shall serve for terms of 3 years
provided that said terms shall be staggered so that terms of at least two
members shall expire each year.
   2.   Filling Vacancies. Upon the occurrence of a vacancy of any member of
the Recreation Commission, the Township Council may by normal procedures
appoint a qualified candidate to fill the unexpired term, taking into
consideration any recommendations of the Recreation Commission.
(Ord. 84, § 2, 4-9-80)
§ 1-804.   Officers.
   1.   Chairman and Secretary. The officers of the Recreation Board shall
consist of a Chairman and a Secretary.
   2.   Duties of Chairman. The Chairman shall preside at all meetings of the
Recreation Commission and shall have the duties normally conferred by
parliamentary usage of such officer.
   3.   Duties of Secretary. The Secretary shall keep the minutes and records
of the Commission and with the assistance of such staff that is available,
shall prepare the agenda of regular and special meetings under the direction of
the Chairman, provide notice of all meetings to the Commission members, attend
to correspondence of the Commission and such other duties as are normally
carried out by the Secretary.
(Ord. 84, § 3, 4-9-80)
§ 1-805.   Election of Officers.
   1.   Annual Organization Meeting. An annual organization meeting shall be
held not later than January 31 of each year.
   2.   Nomination. Nominations shall be made by Commission members from the
floor at the annual organization meeting and election of officers as specified
in § 804(1) shall follow immediately thereafter.
   3.   Majority Vote. A candidate receiving a majority vote of the Recreation
Commission members present shall be declared elected, and shall serve for 1
year or until his successor shall take office.
   4.   Filling Vacancies. Vacancies in office shall be filled immediately by
regular election procedures.
(Ord. 84, § 4, 4-9-80)
§ 1-806.   Meetings.
   1.   Calling of Meetings. Meetings will be called by the Chairman as
required and normally will be held at the Hanover Township Municipal Building
on Saturday mornings beginning at 9 a.m. The Secretary shall notify all members
of the Commission in writing not less than 5 days in advance of such special
meetings.
   2.   Quorum and Voting. A quorum shall consist of 4 members of the
Commission. The number of votes necessary to transact business shall be 4
including abstentions. Voting shall be by roll call. A record of the roll call
vote shall be kept as a part of the minutes.
   3.   Special Meetings. Special meetings may be called by the Chairman. It
shall be the duty of the Chairman to call a special meeting when requested to
do so by a majority of members of the Commission.
   4.   Robert's Rules of Order Govern. Unless otherwise specified, Robert's
Rules of Order shall govern the proceedings at the meetings of this Commission.
(Ord. 84, § 4, 4-9-80)
§ 1-807.   Order of Business.
The order of business at regular meetings shall be:
      A.   Roll Call.
      B.   Reading and Approval of Minutes.
      C.   Correspondence and Bills.
      D.   Old Business.
      E.   New Business.
      F.   Adjournment.
(Ord. 84, Art. 7, 4-9-80)
§ 1-808.   Employees.
Within the limits imposed by the funds available for its use, the Commission
may employ such staff personnel and/or consultants as it sees fit to aid in its
work. Appointments shall be made by a majority vote of the Commission
membership with the approval of the Township Manager.
(Ord. 84, 4-9-80)
§ 1-809.   Budget.
The Commission will meet the first Saturday of September of every year for the
purpose of reviewing present expenditures, considering action on remaining
unexpended appropriations and recommendations to the Township Manager on
appropriations to be considered for the following year.
(Ord. 84, 4-9-80)
B.   Planning Commission.
§ 1-821.   Title.
The name of this organization shall be the Hanover Township (Lehigh County)
Planning Commission.
(Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
§ 1-822.   Authorization to Establish By-Laws.
The authorization for the establishment of these By-laws is pursuant to the
authority of the Township Council under the Hanover Township Home Rule Charter.
(Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
§ 1-823.   Membership.
   1.   Number and Terms. Members shall consist of seven persons to be
appointed by the Township Council. Members shall serve for terms of 4 years
provided that said terms shall be staggered so that terms of at least one
member shall expire each year. All of the members of the Planning Commission
shall be residents of the municipality.
   2.   Filling Vacancies. Upon the occurrence of a vacancy of any member of
the Planning Commission, the Township Council may by normal procedures appoint
a qualified candidate to fill the unexpired term, taking into consideration any
recommendations of the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
§ 1-824.   Officers.
   1.   Chairman, Vice-Chairman, and Secretary. The Officers of the Planning
Commission shall consist of a Chairman, Vice-Chairman and Secretary.
   2.   Duties of Chairman. The Chairman shall preside at all meetings of the
Planning Commission and shall have the duties normally conferred by
parliamentary usage of such officer.
   3.   Duties of Vice-Chairman. In the absence of the Chairman, the Vice-
Chairman shall preside at all meetings of the Planning Commission and shall
have the duties normally conferred by parliamentary usage of such officer.
   4.   Duties of Secretary. The Secretary shall keep the minutes and records
of the Commission and with the assistance of such staff that is available shall
prepare the agenda of regular and special meetings under the direction of the
Chairman, provide notice of all meetings to the Commission and perform such
other duties as are normally carried out by the Secretary.
(Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
§ 1-825.   Election of Officers.
   1.   Annual Organization Meeting. An annual organization meeting shall be
held not later than January 31st of each year.
   2.   Nomination. Nominations shall be made by Commission members from the
floor at the annual organization meeting and election of officers shall follow
immediately thereafter.
   3.   Majority Vote. A candidate receiving a majority vote of the Planning
Commission members present shall be declared elected, and shall serve for one
year or until his successors shall take office.
   4.   Filling Vacancies. Vacancies in office shall be filled immediately by
regular election procedures.
(Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
§ 1-826.   Meetings
   1.   Calling of Meetings. Meetings will be called by the Chairman as
required and normally will be held at the Hanover Township Municipal Building
on the 3rd Tuesday of each month beginning at 7:30 p.m. The Secretary, with the
assistance of such staff as is available, shall notify all members of the
Commission in writing less than 10 days in advance of such meetings.
   2.   Quorum and Voting. A quorum shall consist of a majority of members of
the Planning Commission, not including vacancies. The majority of the members
present in voting shall be necessary to pass any matter before the Commission.
No business shall be transacted unless a quorum is present. A record of the
roll call vote shall be kept as part of the minutes.
   3.   Special Meetings. Special meetings may be called by the Chairman. It
shall be the duty of the Chairman to call a special meeting when requested to
do so by a majority of members of the Commission.
   4.   Robert's Rules of Order Govern. Unless otherwise specified, Robert's
Rules of Order shall govern the proceedings at the meetings of this Commission.
However, the use of Robert's Rules of Order may be waived by a vote of the
quorum.
(Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
§ 1-827.   Order of Business.
The order of business at regular meetings shall be:
      A.   Roll Call.
      B.   Reading and Approval of Minutes.
      C.   Correspondence.
      D.   Unfinished Business.
      E.   New Business.
      F.   Adjournment. (Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
§ 1-828.   Employees.
Within the limits imposed by the funds available for its use, the Commission
may employ such staff personnel and/or consultants as it sees fit to aid in its
work. Appointments shall be made by a majority vote of the Commission
membership with the approval of the Township Manager.
(Ord. 127, 11-10-82)
C.   Lehigh County Tax Collection Committee.
§ 1-841.   Background.
Pennsylvania Act 32 provides for county-wide collection of certain taxes
imposed by municipalities and school districts and, further, provides for the
establishment of a Tax Collection Committee in each county composed of
representatives of such taxing bodies.
(Ord. 496, 8/19/2009)
§ 1-842.   Delegates.
The Township Council shall, by resolution, appoint at least one primary voting
delegate and one first alternate voting delegate to the Lehigh County Tax
Collection Committee. The Township Council may appoint a second alternate
voting delegate.
(Ord. 496, 8/19/2009)
§ 1-843.   Delegates First Appointed.
The first delegates shall be appointed by September 15, 2009, and shall serve a
term until the organizational meeting of the Township Council in January, 2010,
or until their successors are appointed. Thereafter, delegates shall be
appointed annually at the organizational meeting of the Township Council.
(Ord. 496, 8/19/2009)
§ 1-844.   Removal of Delegate from Office.
Delegates may be removed from office at any time by vote of a majority of the
Township Council.
(Ord. 496, 8/19/2009)
§ 1-845.   Vacancies.
Vacancies in the position of delegate or alternate delegate may be filled at
any time by vote of the Township Council.
(Ord. 496, 8/19/2009)
§ 1-846.   Voting.
At any meeting of the Tax Collection Committee, if the primary voting delegate
is not present, the first alternate voting delegate shall be the representative
of the Township, and if neither the primary voting delegate nor the first
alternate voting delegate is present, the second alternate voting delegate (if
any) shall be the representative of the Township.
(Ord. 496, 8/19/2009)
PART 9
FIREMEN'S RELIEF ASSOCIATION
§ 1-901.   Recognition of Firemen's Relief Association.
   1.   The following association is hereby recognized as actively engaged in
providing fire protection and/or emergency services in the Township.
      HAN - LE - CO Fireman's Relief Association
The above named association has been formed for the benefit of its members and
their families in case of death, sickness, temporary or permanent disability or
accident suffered in the line of duty.
   2.   The above named Association of the Township is designated the proper
association(s) to receive such funds as are due and payable to the Township
Treasurer by the Treasurer of the State of Pennsylvania from the tax on
premiums from foreign fire insurance companies.
(Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-902.   Certification to Auditor General.
The Township Council shall annually certify to the Auditor General of the
Commonwealth, the name(s) of the active associations and the percentage of
service they contribute to the protection of the Township. Such certification
shall be on forms prescribed by the Auditor General.
(Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 1-903.   Annual Appropriation.
There is annually appropriated from the Township Treasury all such sums of
money that may hereafter be paid into the Township Treasury by the Treasurer of
the State of Pennsylvania on account of taxes paid on premiums of foreign fire
insurance companies in pursuance of 1984 Act of December 18, No. 205, § 90701
et seq. as hereafter amended, supplemented, modified or reenacted by the
General Assembly of Pennsylvania. Such monies received by the Township
Treasurer from the State Treasurer shall be distributed to the duly recognized
association(s) within 60 days of receipt. The funds shall be distributed on the
basis of the percentage of service established in the certification to the
Auditor General and with other provisions of the Act.
(Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
PART 10
AIRPORT AREA TRANSPORTATION IMPROVEMENT AUTHORITY
§ 1-1001. Organization of Authority.
The Council of the Township of Hanover, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania,
constituting the municipal authority of the said Township as defined in the Act
of Assembly known as the "Municipality Authorities Act of 1945," P.L. 382,
hereby signifies its intention to organize, together with he City of Bethlehem,
and Township of Hanover, Northampton County, an Authority under the provisions
of the said Act of Assembly, its supplements and amendments.
(Ord. 284, 7/1/1992, § 1)
§ 1-1002. Articles of Incorporation.
In pursuance of said intention, the Articles of Incorporation of the said
Authority are hereby approved by the Council on behalf of the said Township in
the following form:
      A.   The name of the Authority is "Airport Area Transportation
Improvement Authority"
      B.   The said Joint Authority is formed under the Municipality
Authorities Act of 1945, approved May 2, 1945, P.L. 382, as amended.
      C.   No other Authority has been organized under said Municipality
Authorities Act of 1945, as amended, or under the Act of June 28, 1935, P.L.
463, and is existence in or for the incorporating municipalities, except:
      (1)   City of Bethlehem.
         (a)   Bethlehem Authority incorporated on August 24, 1938.
         (b)   Bethlehem Housing Authority incorporated on December 5, 1939.
         (c)   Bethlehem Redevelopment Authority incorporated on February 18,
1953.
         (d)   Bethlehem Parking Authority incorporated on May 15, 1970.
         (e)   Lehigh Valley Solid Waste Authority incorporated on April 22,
1985.
      (2)   Township of Hanover, Lehigh County. (a) None.
      (3)   Township of Hanover, Northampton County.
         (a)   Hanover Township Sewer Authority incorporated January 30, 1974.
      D.   The names of the incorporating municipalities are the City of
Bethlehem, Township of Hanover, Lehigh County and Township of Hanover,
Northampton County.
The names and addresses of the municipal officials of said municipalities are:
[Here followed the names and addresses of the municipal officials of said
incorporating municipalities.]
      E.   Composition of Board of Joint Authority.
      (1)   The Board shall consist of seven members. Two members shall be
appointed by the City of Bethlehem. Two members shall be appointed by the Board
of Supervisors of the Township of Hanover, Northampton County. Three members
shall be appointed by the Council of the Township of Hanover, Lehigh County.
      (2)   Each member shall be a taxpayer in, maintain a business in, or be a
citizen (resident) of either the City of Bethlehem, Township of Hanover,
Northampton County, or Township of Hanover, Lehigh County, but no more than one
non-resident may be appointed to the Board from each of the incorporating
municipalities.
      (3)   The term of office for each member of the Board of the Joint
Authority shall commence as of the date of appointment and shall be for a term
as indicated in Subsection (4), below, from the first Monday in January next
succeeding the date of incorporation of the Joint Authority.
      (4)   The names, addresses, appointing municipalities and terms of office
of the first members of the Board of the Joint Authority are: [Here followed
the names, addresses, appointing municipalities, and terms of office of the
first members of the Board of said Authority.]
      (5)   Upon the expiration of the term of any member, the municipality
which has the power of the appointment shall appoint a member of the Board for
a term of 5 years from the date of expiration of the prior term. Any vacancy on
the Board shall be filled (for the unexpired term) by the municipality in the
representation of which the vacancy Occurs.
      (6)   The members of the Board of the Joint Authority shall serve without
compensation, but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred in connection with
their duties as members of the Board.
      F.   The existence of the Joint Authority shall commence on the date of
issuance of the Joint Authority's certificate of incorporation by the Secretary
of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and shall expire 3 months after the date
of final payment on the bonds or other indebtedness issued by the Joint
Authority to finance or refinance the projects described in Subsection (G),
below. The term of existence of the Joint Authority shall only be extended as
provided in the articles of amendment filed with and approved by the Secretary
of the Commonwealth pursuant to applicable provisions of the Municipality
Authorities Act of 1945, as amended.
      G.   The Joint Authority is organized in order to finance, acquire, hold,
construct, improve, maintain, operate, own and lease, either as lessor or
lessee, either individually or by agreement with any other corporation,
municipality, authority or the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania (including its
departments and agencies), transportation facilities or business improvement
projects in the area known as the "Airport Area Transportation Network" either
on property acquired by the Authority or within the rights-of-way of local,
State or Federal. roadways including, but not limited to, bridges, tunnels,
highways, parkways, local streets, roads, sidewalks, passageways, roadbeds,
traffic control systems, traffic distribution centers, parking spaces and all
facilities and rights-of-way necessary or incident thereto, all as described in
the plan approved by the governing bodies of the incorporating municipalities
pursuant to subsection (H), hereto. To these ends, the Joint Authority is
authorized to exercise all those powers enumerated in Section 4(B) of the
Municipalities Authorities Act of 1945, as amended, and in the Transportation
Partnership Act, approved July 9, 1985, P.L. 187; provided, however, that the
Joint Authority shall comply with the procedures set forth in Section 4(E) of
the Municipality Authorities Act of 1945, as amended, prior to its approval and
implementation of any proposed project.
      H.   The City of Bethlehem, Township of Hanover, Lehigh County, and
Township of Hanover, Northampton County, have retained the right existing under
the Municipality Authorities Act of 1945, as amended, and under the
Transportation Partnership Act to approve the plan for improvements, together
with estimated costs and proposed methods of assessments, for any project
undertaken by the Joint Authority in the Transportation Development and
Business Improvement District to be designated, or from time to time
redesignated, by the mutual agreement of the governing bodies of the
incorporating municipalities.
(Ord. 284, 7/1/1992, § 2)
§ 1-1003. Appointment of Members.
The first members of the Joint Authority named in the proposed Articles of
Incorporation (and identified therein as appointees of this Township) are
hereby specifically appointed* members of said Board for the terms of office
set forth after their respective names.
(Ord. 284, 7/1/1992, § 3)
§ 1-1004. Execution of Articles of Incorporation.
The Chairman and members of the Council of the Township of Hanover Township,
Lehigh County, are hereby authorized and directed to execute said Articles of
Incorporation on behalf of said Township, and the Secretary of the Township is
authorized and directed to attest said signatures and affix thereto the seal of
said Township, cause a notice of intention to file said Articles of
Incorporation to be published once in the legal periodical of Lehigh County and
once in a newspaper published and of general circulation in such County, and to
file a certified copy of this Part, together with proofs of publication of the
notice of the public meeting and the notice of intention to file said Articles
of Incorporation, with the Secretary of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania,
accompanied by the required filing fee as provided by said "Municipality
Authorities Act of 1945," its supplements and amendments.
(Ord. 284, 7/1/1992, § 4)
§ 1-1005. Payment of Fee.
An order is to be drawn on the Treasurer of said Township of Hanover, Lehigh
County, to pay the required fee for filing said Articles of Incorporation and
the amount necessary to pay said fee is hereby appropriated from the general
treasury of the said Township of Hanover, Lehigh County.
(Ord. 284, 7/1/1992, § 5)
* Ord. 284 read "appointment."
PART 11
OPEN RECORDS POLICY
§ 1-1101.   Introduction.
Hanover Township hereby establishes the following open records policy which is
intended to further and be consistent with the requirements of the Pennsylvania
Right to Know Law (Act 3 of 2008) as the same may be hereafter amended (the
“Law”).
(Res. 2008-37, 12/3/2008)
§ 1-1102.   Open Records Officer.
   1.   The Office of Open Records Officer is established and shall perform the
responsibilities of such officer as set forth in the Law and this policy.
   2.   The Open Records Officer shall be appointed by the Township Council.
The Township may appoint an alternate Open Records Officer to serve in the
absence of the Open Records Officer.
   3.   Functions.
      A.   The Open Records Officer shall receive requests submitted to the
Township under the Law, direct requests to other appropriate persons within the
Township or to appropriate persons in another agency, track the Township’s
progress in responding to requests and issue interim and final responses under
this act.
      B.   Upon receiving a request for a public record or financial records,
the Open Records Officer shall do all of the following:
         (1)   Note the date of receipt on the written request.
         (2)   Compute the day on which the 5 business day period under § 901
of the Law will expire and make a notation of that date on the written request.
         (3)   Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request,
including all documents submitted with the request until the request has been
fulfilled. If the request is denied, the written request shall be maintained
for 30 days or, if an appeal is filed, until a final determination is issued
under § 1101(b) of the Law or the appeal is deemed denied.
      C.   The Open Records Officer shall post and maintain as current both in
the Township Building and on the Township's website the following information:
         (1)   Contact information for the Open Records Officer.
         (2)   Contact information for the Pennsylvania Office of Open Records.
         (3)   The approved form for filing a request.
         (4)   A copy of this Open Records Policy.
         (5)   Current fees for duplication of records as established by the
Pennsylvania Open Records Office.
(Res. 2008-37, 12/3/2008)
§ 1-1103.   Requests.
   1.   Public records will be available for inspection at the Township
municipal building during normal business hours, Monday through Friday, 8:30
a.m. to 4 p.m., with the exception of holidays.
   2.   The Open Records Officer may accept requests that are verbal or in
writing. Anonymous requests will not be considered. However, if the requestor
wishes to pursue the relief and remedies provided for in the law, the request
must be in writing.
   3.   Written requests shall be directed to the Open Records Officer at the
Township Municipal Building, 2202 Grove Road, Allentown, PA 18109, and may be
submitted in person, by mail, by e-mail or by facsimile. Written requests shall
be on a form approved by the Township or approved by the Pennsylvania Office of
Open Records and shall include the date of the request, the name and address of
the requester and a clear description of the records sought. An approved form
is attached as Exhibit “A” to this policy.
(Res. 2008-37, 12/3/2008; as amended by Res. 2024-44, 8/21/2024)
§ 1-1104.   Fees.
   1.   If not otherwise established herein, fees for duplication by
photocopying, printing from electronic media or microfilm, copying onto
electronic media, transmission by facsimile or other electronic means and other
means of duplication shall be as determined by Council and permitted by the
Pennsylvania Office of Open Records.
   2.   If a record is maintained only electronically or in other non-paper
media, duplication fees shall be limited to the lesser of the fee for
duplication on paper or the fee for duplication in the original media unless
the requester specifically requests for the record to be duplicated in the more
expensive medium.
Page Revised 3/2025 (ALP S-15)   1-84
      (CH. 1, Part 11, § 1-1105)
   3.   If the Township necessarily incurs costs for complying with the
request, other than review of a record to determine whether it is a public
record, such reasonable fees may be imposed at the direction of the Open
Records Officer.
   4.   If mailing is requested, the cost of postage will be charged.
   5.   If “true and correct certification” is requested, an additional charge
as determined by Council and permitted by the Pennsylvania Office of Open
Records will be added.
   6.   The Township will require prepayment if the total fees are estimated to
exceed $100.
(Res. 2008-37, 12/3/2008; as amended by Res. 2024-44, 8/21/2024)
§ 1-1105.   Response.
   1.   The Township will make a good faith effort to provide the requested
public records as promptly as feasible. Township employees shall cooperate with
those requesting to review and/or duplicate original Township documents while
taking reasonable measures to protect Township documents from the possibility
of theft and/or modification.
   2.   The Open Records Officer shall review all written requests for access
to public records. As soon as possible, not later than 5 business days after
receiving a written request to access public records, the Open Records Officer
shall respond to all such requests in a manner consistent with the Law.
(Res. 2008-37, 12/3/2008)
§ 1-1106.   Appeal Process.
If a written request is denied or deemed denied, the requester may file with
the Pennsylvania Office of Open Records within 15 business days of the mailing
date of the Township’s denial. The exceptions shall state grounds on which the
requester asserts that the record is a public record and shall address any
grounds stated by the Township for denying the request.
(Res. 2008-37, 12/3/2008)

PART 12
   RED FLAG POLICIES
§ 1-1201.   Red Flag Policies.
This Part shall be known as the “Hanover Township Red Flag Policies.”
(Ord. 507, 10/20/2010, § 1)
§ 1-1202.   Background.
The Federal Trade Commission has adopted identity theft rules (“rules”)
requiring the creation of certain policies relating to the detection,
prevention and mitigation of identity theft. The rules adopted as 16 C.F.R. §
681.2, require creditors to adopt “red flag policies” to detect, prevent and
mitigate identity theft with respect to covered accounts. The rules include
utility companies in the definition of creditor. The Township of Hanover is a
creditor by virtue of providing utility services, namely public water and
sanitary sewer services, and accepting payment for such services in arrears.
Township utility customer accounts for such services are covered accounts as
defined by the rules. The purpose of this Part is to comply with the
requirements of the rules by establishing red flag policies.
(Ord. 507, 10/20/2010, § 1)
§ 1-1203.   Definitions.
   PUBLIC WATER SERVICES—the services of providing potable water to properties
located in the Township pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 26 of the Statutory Code.
   SERVICED PROPERTY—a property in the Township receiving utility service.
   SEWER SERVICES—sanitary sewer services provided by the Township to
properties located in the Township pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 18 of the Statutory Code.
   TOWNSHIP—Hanover Township, Lehigh County.
   UTILITY ACCOUNTS—all accounts maintained by the Township for the purpose of
accumulating, billing and collection of utility charges.
   UTILITY CHARGES—those fees or costs charged by the Township to utility
customers for utility service.
   UTILITY CUSTOMER—the record owner or owners of a serviced property, as
determined from the records of the Tax Assessment Office of Lehigh County, PA.
   UTILITY SERVICE—sewer services and/or public water services.
(Ord. 507, 10/20/2010, § 1)
§ 1-1204.   Identity Theft Protection.
   1.   All utility accounts for serviced properties shall be established only
in the name of and with a billing address of the utility customer.
   2.   All bills, statements or other communications regarding utility charges
will be delivered by U.S. mail to the address of utility customer.
   3.   Upon the sale of a serviced property, the name and address on a utility
account for such serviced property shall be changed to the name and address of
the new utility customer as determined from the records of the Tax Assessment
Office of Lehigh County, PA.
   4.   A utility account shall not be opened in the name of a tenant or any
person other than the utility customer. Duplicate bills may be sent to any
other person or address at the request of a utility customer.
   5.   Payment for utility charges shall be accepted only in cash, bank check,
certified check or money order. Credit cards or debit cards will not be
accepted.
(Ord. 507, 10/20/2010, § 1)
§ 1-1205.   Detecting Red Flags.
Township personnel responsible for establishment, billing and collection of
utility accounts shall notify the Township Manager upon return of billing
statements because of incorrect address or incorrect name or other circumstance
suggesting an uncertainty as to the identity of the utility customer. The
Township Manager shall take appropriate action to confirm that the proper
person or entity is receiving statements of utility charges for the serviced
property.
(Ord. 507, 10/20/2010, § 1)
§ 1-1206.   Updating Red Flag Policies.
At least once each calendar year, the Township Manager shall review this red
flags policy to determine whether it requires updating in response to changes
in Township procedures with regard to utility services, additional extensions
of credit to the public for other Township services, changes in technology or
other improvements that are identified for the policy.
(Ord. 507, 10/20/2010, § 1)
§ 1-1207.   Administration.
   1.   The Township Manager shall be responsible for oversight of the red
flags policy.
   2.   The Township Manager shall assure that all employees with authority to
establish utility accounts, issue billing statements for utility accounts or
collect utility accounts are aware of and comply with the red flag policies.
(Ord. 507, 10/20/2010, § 1)

Part 1
Control and Licensing of Animals
§ 101. Definitions.
The following words or phrases when used in this Part shall have the meaning
ascribed to them in this section unless the context clearly indicates
otherwise. Also, personal pronouns shall include the singular as well as the
plural number and the male, female and neuter gender.
   ANIMAL - means all quadrapeds, both male and female, including but not
limited to cats and dogs.
   AT LARGE - means off the premises of the owner and not under the control of
the owner or his agent, either by leash, cord, chain or otherwise.
   OWNER - means and includes every person, firm or corporation having a right
of property in any animal which is kept, harbored or comes within the Township,
as well as every person, firm or corporation occupying any premises within the
Township which permits any animal on or about its premises.
   TOWNSHIP - means Township of Hanover, County of Lehigh, Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 98, § 1, 2-11-81)
§ 102. Collar and License Tag.
   1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, or harbor within the
Township any dog six months or older unless such is licensed by the Treasurer
of the proper county in which it is kept and unless such animal wears a collar
and license tag.
   2.   This section is not intended to apply to dogs whose owners are
nonresidents and are temporarily within the Township nor to dogs brought into
the Township for breeding, trail, or show purposes nor any "seeing-eye" dog
properly trained to assist blind persons when such dog is actually used by a
blind person for the purpose of going from place to place.
(Ord. 98, § 1, 2-11-81)
§ 103. Running at Large Prohibited.
No owner shall permit any animal to run at large in the Township.
(Ord. 98, § 1, 2-11-81)
§ 104. Seizing of Dogs.
Any Township officer may seize any dog found at large in Township of Hanover.
Such dogs are to be impounded in a licensed kennel.
(Ord. 98, as added by Ord. 212, 5-11-68)
§ 105. Licensed Dogs.
Owners of licensed dogs are to be notified by registered or certified mail,
with return receipt, that the dog is impounded and will be disposed of in five
days if not claimed. Five days after the return receipt has been received, and
the dog has not been claimed, the dog may be sold or destroyed in accordance
with the 1982 Dog Law.
(Ord. 98, as added by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 106. Unlicensed Dogs.
Unlicensed dogs that are seized are to be held in such kennel for forty-eight
(48) hours and if not claimed my be destroyed in accordance with the 1982 Dog
Law.
(Ord. 98, as added by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 107. Penalty.
The first two times a dog is seized, the owner shall pay a fine of fifteen
dollars ($15.00) to the Township of Hanover as well as reasonable fees for
keeping the animal in a kennel.
Any person allowing an animal to run at large a third time in violation of this
Part shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more
than three hundred dollars ($300.00); and/or to imprisonment for a term not to
exceed ninety (90) days.
(Ord. 98, as added by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
Part 2
Animal Defecation
§ 201. Animal Defecation on Public and Private Property Restricted.
No person, having possession, custody or control of any animals, shall
knowingly or negligently permit any dog or other animal to commit any nuisance,
i.e. defecation or urination, upon any gutter, street, driveway, alley, curb or
sidewalk in the Township of Hanover, or upon the floors or stairways of any
building or place frequented by the public or used in common by the tenants, or
upon the outside walls, walkways, driveways, alleys, curbs or stairways of any
building abutting on a public street or park, or upon the grounds of any public
park or public area, or upon any private property other than the property of
the owner of such animal.
(Ord. 85, 4-9-80; as revised by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 202. Disposal of Animal Feces.
Any person having possession, custody or control of any dog or other animal
which commits a nuisance, i.e. dedication of urination, in any area other than
the private property of the owner of such dog or other animal, as prohibited in
§
101 shall be required to immediately remove any deces from such surface and
either:
   1.   Carry same way for disposal in a toilet
   2.   Place same in a nonleaking container for deposit in a trash or litter
receptacle.
(Ord. 85, 4-9-80; as revised by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 203. Dogs Accompanying Blind or Handicapped Persons Exempted.
The provisions of §§
201 and 200 hereof shall not apply to a guide dog accompanying any blind
person, or to a dog used to assist any other physically handicapped person.
(Ord. 85, 4-9-80; as revised by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 204. Penalties.
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this Part
shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than
three hundred dollars ($300.00), or to imprisonment for a term not to exceed
ninety (90) days.
(Ord. 85, 4-9-80; as revised by Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
Part 3
Noise Nuisances
§ 301. Intent and Purpose.
The Township Council of the Township of Hanover, finding that excessive levels
of sound are detrimental to the physical, mental and social well-being of the
people as well as to their comfort, living conditions, general welfare and
safety and being therefor a public health and welfare hazard, hereby declares
it to be necessary to provide for the greater control and more effective
regulation of excessive sound and the sources of excessive sound within the
Township.
(Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 302. Noise Disturbance.
It shall be illegal within the Township for any person or persons to own,
possess, harbor, or control any animal or bird which makes any noise
continuously and/or incessantly for a period of ten minutes or makes such noise
intermittently for one-half (1/2) hour or more to the disturbance of any person
any time of the day or night regardless of whether the animal or bird is
physically situated in or upon private property, said noise being a nuisance;
provided, that at the time the animal or bird is making such noise no person is
trespassing or threatening to trespass upon private property in or upon which
the animal or bird is situated nor is there any other legitimate cause which
justifiably provoked the animal or bird.
(Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 303. Exceptions.
This Part shall not be deemed to prohibit or otherwise declare unlawful any
agricultural operations protected from the nuisance suits by Act. No. 1982-133.
(Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
§ 304. Penalties.
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this Part,
shall upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than
three hundred dollars ($300.00), and/or to imprisonment for a term not to
exceed ninety (90) days.
(Ord. 212, 5-11-88)
Part 4
Maximum Number of Animals
§ 401. Purpose.
   1.   This Part is enacted to regulate the maintenance, keeping or possession
of animals within the Township in order to promote the health, safety and
general welfare of its inhabitants.
   2.   Where the provisions of this Part impose greater restrictions than
those of any other statute, ordinance, regulation or resolution, the provisions
of this Part shall be controlling. Where the provisions of any other statute,
ordinance, regulation or resolution impose greater restrictions than this Part,
the provisions of such other statute, ordinance, regulation or resolution shall
be controlling.
   3.   The Township Council makes the following legislative finding, and finds
that:
      A.   Nuisance and conditions detrimental to the public health, safety and
welfare have been created by the keeping of multiple animals on premises within
the Township or the presence of certain animals in the Township.
      B.   The nuisances and conditions detrimental to the public health,
safety and welfare include, but are not limited to: accumulation of animal
waste, spread of infections or contagious diseases, and/or the danger of insect
infestation, smell and noise.
      C.   Limiting the number of animals on premises within the Township and
prohibiting the keeping of certain animals within the Township will alleviate
or, at a minimum, help alleviate these conditions.
      D.   Limiting the number of animals to not more than six (6) and
requiring the issuance of permits for additional animals exceeding six (6) will
alleviate or, at a minimum, help alleviate these conditions.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 401)
§ 402. Definitions.
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this Part:
   ANIMAL - construed in a literal sense to include not only mammals, but also
birds, fish, reptiles and insects.
   EXHIBITION PERMIT - a permit issued pursuant to §
410 of this Part.
   OFFICER - any duly appoint animal control officer or his/her designee.
   PERSON - any individual, partnership, association, corporation, company,
firm, institution, trustee, estate, trust, any private entity or public entity
as well as all officers, agents, servants, employees or others acting for any
of the same, and shall be taken as applying in the singular or plural as the
case may require.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 402)
§ 403. Limitation on Number of Animals.
Except for species of fish, it shall be unlawful to keep more than six (6)
animals six (6) months of age or older on any premises, regardless of the
number of owners; provided, however, that this Section shall not apply to any
premises on which a commercial kennel, animal shelter, pet store or veterinary
clinic is operated in accordance with applicable Township ordinances nor if an
exhibition permit has been issued and is in effect pursuant to § 410 of this
Part.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 403)
§ 404. Nuisances.
   1.   When not confined to the owner's premises, all dogs must be under the
physical control of their owner or custodian and physically restrained by a
leash or other restraining device at all times.
   2.   No person owning, harboring, keeping or in charge of any animal shall
cause or allow such animal to defecate on any sidewalk, play area, park or any
place where people congregate or walk or any public property whatsoever or on
any private property, without the permission of the owner of said property. The
restriction in this Section shall not apply to the portion of the street lying
between the curb line in any common thoroughfare, passageway or bypath which
shall be used to curb such animals under the following conditions:
      A.   The person who so curbs such animal shall immediately remove all
feces deposited by such animal by any sanitary and reasonable manner.
      B.   The feces removed from the aforementioned designated area shall be
disposed of in a sanitary manner by the person owning, harboring, keeping or in
charge of any animal curbed in accordance with the provisions hereof.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 404)
§ 405. Cattle, Sheep, Swine, Goats in the Township Prohibited.
No person shall keep or maintain any cattle, sheep, swine or goats within the
Township, except on farms, places where animals are kept for slaughtering, for
laboratory purposes or when kept subject to an exhibition permit.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 405)
§ 406. Certain Animals and Fowl in Dwellings Prohibited.
No pigeons, turkeys, chickens, ducks, geese or other feathered animals shall be
kept or maintained in any dwelling, apartment, flat or tenement.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 406)
§ 407. Rabbits, Guinea Pigs and Fowl at Large.
Rabbits, guinea pigs or fowl shall not be allowed to run at large, but shall be
confined in a suitable building or coop with an enclosed and covered runway.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 407)
§ 408. Coops to Be Kept Clean.
A building or coop in which animals are kept must be thoroughly clean at all
times and shall be cleaned at least once every week.
(Ord. 431 1/13/2003, § 408)
§ 409. Distance of Coons from Occupied Dwellings; Distance of Animals from Food
Stands.
No part of a building, coop or runway in which rabbits, guinea pigs or fowl are
kept shall be less than thirty (30) feet from the doors or windows of any
building occupied by human beings whether for dwelling or business purposes.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 409)
§ 410. Exhibition Permit.
A person may keep animals in the Township otherwise prohibited by this Part for
a period of not more than ten (10) days in association with a fair, rodeo,
exhibition or similar event, provided the same is conducted in accordance with
any other applicable ordinances of the Township, upon the issuance of an
exhibition permit by the Township. The Township shall issue such exhibition
permit upon the payment of a fee, to be determined by resolution of the
Township Council, and the submission of an application describing the name and
address of the applicant, the owner of the animals, the number and type of
animals for which the permit is requested, the type of event, the location of
the event and the dates of the event.
(Ord. 431 1/13/2003, § 410)
§ 411. Animal Control Officer.
   1.   The Township Manager of Hanover Township shall appoint an Animal
Control Officer. In addition, the Township Manager may from time to time
designate a temporary animal control officer.
   2.   The Animal Control Officer of the Township is authorized hereby to
enter upon any premises within the Township for the purpose of investigating a
possible violation of this Part. If access is denied by the property owner, the
Animal Control Officer is authorized to submit an application for a search
warrant to the appropriate judicial authority.
(Ord. 431, 1/13/2003, § 411)
§ 412. Penalty.
Any person who violates any provision of this Part shall be subject to the
following penalties:
   A.   First violation - a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   Second violation - a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   C.   Third violation - a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   D.   Fourth and each subsequent violation - a fine of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00).
   E.   Each day's failure to comply with any provisions of this Part shall
constitute a separate violation.
(Ord. 431 1/13/2003, § 412)
§ 413. Additional Enforcement Remedies.
In addition, the Officer may institute in the name of the Township any
appropriate action or proceeding, whether by legal process or otherwise to
restrain, correct or abate a continuing violation of any provision of this Part
or any rules and regulations made pursuant hereto.
(Ord. 431 1/13/2003, § 413)
